Endangered Species Act requires federal agencies conducting, authorizing or funding activities that affect threatened or endangered species to ensure that those effects do not jeopardize the continued existence of listed species. The Council has concluded that the Proposed Action and the prosecution of the multispecies fishery are not likely to jeopardize any ESA-listed species or alter or modify any critical habitat. NMFS has already concurred with that conclusion. The Council does acknowledge that endangered and threatened species may be affected by the measures proposed, but impacts should be minimal especially when seen in light of the large reductions in fishing effort being implemented. Section 7.5 contains the potential impacts on listed species of the Proposed Action. 9.4 MARINE MAMMAL PROTECTION ACT Section 7.5 contains the potential impacts on marine mammals of the Proposed Action. The Council has reviewed the impacts of Amendment 18 on marine mammal species and has concluded that the management actions contained in this action are consistent with the provisions of the MMPA. The take of harbor porpoise under the existing FMP have been reduced to the point that would allow the stocks to achieve optimum levels. The level of take for the remaining odontocetes and seals that are affected by this fishery are low enough, in relation to the size of their populations, that it has been determined that the stocks would be allowed to achieve optimum levels. Therefore, since the mortality and serious injury that is likely to occur under the existing FMP has been assessed relative to the PBR allowed for each species under the MMPA and found to be below those levels, the Council concludes that Amendment 18 will provide ongoing protection to these species. 9.5 COASTAL ZONE MANAGEMENT ACT Section 307(c)(1) of the Federal Coastal Zone Management Act (CZMA) of 1972 requires that all Federal activities that directly affect the coastal zone be consistent with approved state coastal zone management programs to the maximum extent practicable. Pursuant to Section 930.36(c) of the regulations implementing the CZMA, NMFS made a general consistency determination that the Northeast Multispecies Fishery Management Plan (FMP), including Amendment 16, and Framework Adjustment 53, is consistent to the maximum extent practicable with the enforceable policies of the approved coastal management program of Maine, New Hampshire, Massachusetts, Rhode Island, Connecticut, New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Delaware, Maryland, Virginia, and North Carolina. This general consistency determination applies to the current NE Multispecies FMP, and all subsequent routine federal actions carried out in accordance with the FMP such as Framework Adjustments and specifications. A general consistency determination is warranted because Framework Adjustments to the FMP are 356 repeated activities that adjust the use of management tools previously implemented in the FMP. A general consistency determination avoids the necessity of issuing separate consistency determinations for each incremental action. This determination was submitted to the above states on October 21, 2009. To date, the states of North Carolina, Rhode Island, Virginia, Connecticut, New Hampshire, and Pennsylvania have concurred with the General Consistency Determination. Consistency was inferred for those states that did not respond. 9.6 ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES ACT Amendment 18 was developed in compliance with the requirements of the Administrative Procedures Act, and these requirements will continue to be followed when the proposed regulation is published. Section 553 of the Administrative Procedure Act establishes procedural requirements applicable to informal rulemaking by Federal agencies. The purpose of these requirements is to ensure public access to the Federal rulemaking process, and to give the public adequate notice and opportunity for comment. At this time, the Council is not requesting any abridgement of the rulemaking process for this action. 9.7 DATA QUALITY ACT Pursuant to NOAA guidelines implementing Section 515 of Public Law 106-554 (the Data Quality Act), all information products released to the public must first undergo a Pre-Dissemination Review to ensure and maximize the quality, objectivity, utility, and integrity of the information (including statistical information) disseminated by or for Federal agencies. This section addresses these requirements. 9.7.1 Utility of Information Product The information presented in this document is helpful to the intended users (the affected public) by presenting a clear description of the purpose and need of the Proposed Action, the measures proposed, and the impacts of those measures. A discussion of the reasons for selecting the Proposed Action is included so that intended users may have a full understanding of the Proposed Action and its implications. Until a proposed rule is prepared and published, this document is the principal means by which the information contained herein is available to the public. The information provided in this document is based on the most recent available information from the relevant data sources. The development of this document and the decisions made by the Council to propose this action are the result of a multi-stage public process, and the information pertaining to management measures contained in this document has been improved based on comments from the public, the fishing industry, members of the Council, and NOAA NMFS. This document is available in several formats, including printed publication, CD-ROM, and online through the Council’s web page in PDF format. The Federal Register notice that announces the proposed rule and the final rule and implementing regulations will be made available in printed publication, on the GARFO website, and through the Regulations.gov website. The Federal Register documents will provide metric conversions for all measurements. 9.7.2 Integrity of Information Product Prior to dissemination, information associated with this action, independent of the specific intended distribution mechanism, is safeguarded from improper access, modification, or 357 destruction, to a degree commensurate with the risk and magnitude of harm that could result from the loss, misuse, or unauthorized access to or modification of such information. All electronic information disseminated by NOAA NMFS adheres to the standards set out in Appendix III, “Security of Automated Information Resources,” of OMB Circular A-130; the Computer Security Act; and the Government Information Security Act. All confidential information (e.g., dealer purchase reports) is safeguarded pursuant to the Privacy Act; Titles 13, 15, and 22 of the U.S. Code (confidentiality of census, business, and financial information); the Confidentiality of Statistics provisions of the Magnuson-Stevens Act; and NOAA Administrative Order 216-100, Protection of Confidential Fisheries Statistics. 9.7.3 Objectivity of Information Product For purposes of the Pre-Dissemination Review, this document is considered to be a “Natural Resource Plan.” Accordingly, the document adheres to the published standards of the MSFCMA; the Operational Guidelines, Fishery Management Plan Process; the EFH Guidelines; the National Standard Guidelines; and NOAA Administrative Order 216-6, Environmental Review Procedures for Implementing the NEPA. This information product uses information of known quality from sources acceptable to the relevant scientific and technical communities. Stock status (including estimates of biomass and fishing mortality) reported in this product are based on either assessments subject to peer-review through the Stock Assessment Review Committee or on updates of those assessments prepared by scientists of the Northeast Fisheries Science Center. These update assessments were reviewed for TRAC by the Integrated Peer Review, SAW/SARC 59, and 2014 Groundfish Updates and Peer Review, which all included participation by independent stock assessment scientists. Landing and revenue information is based on information collected through the VTR and Commercial Dealer databases. Information on catch composition, by tow, is based on reports collected by the NOAA NMFS observer program and incorporated into the sea sampling or observer database systems. These reports are developed using an approved, scientifically valid sampling process. In addition to these sources, additional information is presented that has been accepted and published in peer-reviewed journals or by scientific organizations. Original analyses in this document were prepared using data from accepted sources, and the analyses have been reviewed by members of the Groundfish PDT. Despite current data limitations, the conservation and management measures proposed for this action were selected based upon the best scientific information available. The analyses conducted in support of the Preferred Alternative were conducted using information from the most recent complete calendar years, through 2013, and in some cases includes information that was collected during the first eight months of calendar year 2014. Complete data were not available for calendar year 2014. The data used in the analyses provide the best available information on the number of harvesters in the fishery, the catch (including landings and discards) by those harvesters, the sales and revenue of those landings to dealers, the type of permits held by vessels, the number of DAS used by those vessels, the catch of recreational fishermen and the location of those catches, and the catches and revenues from various special management programs. Specialists (including professional members of plan development teams, technical teams, committees, and Council staff) who worked with these data are familiar with the most current analytical techniques and with the available data and information relevant to the groundfish fishery. 358 The policy choices are clearly articulated in this EIS (Section 4.0), as the management alternatives considered in this action. The supporting science and analyses, upon which the policy choices are based, are summarized and described in Section 7.0. All supporting materials, information, data, and analyses within this document have been, to the maximum extent practicable, properly referenced according to commonly accepted standards for scientific literature to ensure transparency. The review process used in preparation of this document involves the responsible Council, the NEFSC, GARFO, and NOAA NMFS Headquarters. The NEFSC’s technical review is conducted by senior level scientists with specialties in population dynamics, stock assessment methods, demersal resources, population biology, and the social sciences. The Council review process involves public meetings at which affected stakeholders have opportunity to provide comments on the document. Review by GARFO staff is conducted by those with expertise in fisheries management and policy, habitat conservation, protected species, and compliance with the applicable law. Final approval of the action proposed in this document and clearance of any rules prepared to implement resulting regulations is conducted by staff at NOAA FMFS Headquarters, the Department of Commerce, and the U.S. Office of Management and Budget. 9.8 EXECUTIVE ORDER 13132 (FEDERALISM) Executive Order 13132 established nine fundamental federalism principles for Federal agencies to follow when developing and implementing actions with federalism implications. The E.O. also lists a series of policy making criteria to which Federal agencies must adhere when formulating and implementing policies that have federalism implications. However, no federalism issues or implications have been identified relative to the measures proposed in Amendment 18. This action does not contain policies with federalism implications sufficient to warrant preparation of an assessment under E.O. 13132. The affected states have been closely involved in the development of the proposed management measures through their representation on the Council (all affected states are represented as voting members of at least one Regional Fishery Management Council). No comments were received from any state officials relative to any federalism implications that may be associated with this action. 9.9 EXECUTIVE ORDER 13158 (MARINE PROTECTED AREAS) Executive Order 13158 on Marine Protected Areas requires each federal agency whose actions affect the natural or cultural resources that are protected by a MPA to identify such actions, and, to the extent permitted by law and to the maximum extent practicable, in taking such actions, avoid harm to the natural and cultural resources that are protected by an MPA. The E.O. directs federal agencies to refer to the MPAs identified in a list of MPAs that meet the definition of MPA for the purposes of the Order. The E.O. requires that the Departments of Commerce and the Interior jointly publish and maintain such a list of MPAs. As of the date of submission of this document, the list of MPA sites has not been developed by the departments. No further guidance related to this Executive Order is available at this time. 9.10 PAPERWORK REDUCTION ACT The purpose of the Paperwork Reduction Act (PRA) is to control and, to the extent possible, minimize the paperwork burden for individuals, small businesses, nonprofit institutions, and other persons resulting from the collection of information by or for the Federal Government. The 359 authority to manage information and recordkeeping requirements is vested with the Director of the Office of Management and Budget (OMB). This authority encompasses establishment of guidelines and policies, approval of information collection requests, and reduction of paperwork burdens and duplications. The Proposed Action in Amendment 18 would modify existing collection of information requirements implemented by previous amendments to the FMP that are subject to the PRA. Specifically, entities that exceed the PSC aggregate cap would be required to identify the MRI/permit to set-aside and render unusable each fishing year. This would be done through a permitting form through NMFS. The PRA package prepared in support of this action and the information collection identified above, including the required forms and supporting statements, will be submitted when the Proposed Action is determined and the final amendment is submitted. 9.11 REGULATORY IMPACT REVIEW This Regulatory Impact Review (RIR) is framed around the preferred alternatives selected by the New England Fishery Management Council for Amendment 18 to the Northeast Multispecies (Groundfish) Fishery Management Plan. The preferred alternatives were selected at the September 2015 Council meeting in Plymouth, MA. 9.11.1 Executive Order 12866 (Regulatory Planning and Review) The purpose of Executive Order 12866 is to enhance planning and coordination with respect to new and existing regulations. This E.O. requires the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) to review regulatory programs that are considered to be “significant.” E.O. 12866 requires a review of proposed regulations to determine whether or not the expected effects would be significant, where a significant action is any regulatory action that may: 1. Have an annual effect on the economy of $100 million or more, or adversely affect in a material way the economy, a sector of the economy, productivity, jobs, the environment, public health or safety, or State, local, or tribal governments or communities; 2. Create a serious inconsistency or otherwise interfere with an action taken or planned by another agency; 3. Materially alter the budgetary impact of entitlements, grants, user fees, or loan programs or the rights and obligations of recipients thereof; or 4. Raise novel legal or policyissues arising out of legal mandates, the President’s priorities, or the principles set forth in the Executive Order. 9.11.1.1 Objectives The goals of Amendment 18 to the Northeast Multispecies FMP, as well as the goals and objectives of the FMP itself, are provided in Section 3.3 of this document. 9.11.1.2 Description A description of the entities affected by this amendment, specifically the stakeholders of the New England Groundfish Fishery, is provided in Section 6.5 of this document. 9.11.1.3 Problem Statement The purpose and need for the actions proposed in this amendment is provided in Section 3.2 of this document and are incorporated herein by reference. 360 9.11.1.4 Analysis of Alternatives This section provides an analysis of each preferred alternative selected for Amendment 18 at the September 2015 Council meeting, as mandated by E.O. 12866. This analysis focuses on the expected changes in net benefits and costs to stakeholders of the Northeast groundfish fishery. Much of this information is provided in Section 7.6 of this document. Table 109 highlights the Amendment 18 goal(s) and Magnuson Stevens Act National Standard(s) most relevant to each section of alternatives. This list should not be considered exhaustive. 9.11.1.4.1 Accumulation Limits Goal 1 of Amendment 18 is to “promote a diverse groundfish fishery, including different gear types, vessel sizes, ownership patterns, geographic locations, and levels of participation through sectors and permit banks.” Additionally, Goal 4 of Amendment 18 is to “prevent any individual(s), corporation(s), or other entity(ies) from acquiring or controlling excessive shares of the fishery access privileges.” Keeping these goals in mind, consolidation has occurred in the groundfish fishery under the catch share system (Section 6.5.4), and the ownership of excessive shares by an individual or entity has been viewed as a potential problem. The Council contracted with Compass Lexicon to determine whether excessive shares exist in the Northeast multispecies fishery today (Section 6.5.4.4) and to recommend an accumulation limit that would prevent excessive shares from occurring. Compass Lexicon defined excessive shares as the level where market power may be exerted, recommending a PSC limit of 15.5 to prevent this possibility. It determined that a limit on permit holdings alone would not prevent market power. Short term impacts of preferred alternatives PSC limit: Alternative 6 was selected as the preferred alternative for a limit on PSC holdings (Section 4.1.2.7); it would limit the average PSC an entity can hold across all allocated stocks to 15.5. There are currently 15 allocated stocks, amounting to an aggregate cap of 232.5 PSC. The highest aggregate PSC held by an individual or permit bank as of FY2014 is 140.4, an increase of 38 from the high of 102.4 during FY2010 (Table 50). Given this somewhat modest increase under the catch share system, an increase of nearly 100 PSC (to reach the limit) would be unlikely to occur over the next few years and Alternative 6 is expected to result in no change in net benefits in the short term. Additionally, under Alternative 6, the preferred Option (D) for disposition of current holdings in excess of what is allowed would not apply to any individual in the groundfish fishery upon Amendment 18 implementation. Permit/MRI limit: Alternative 2 was selected as the preferred alternative for a limit on MRIs (Section 4.1.3.2); it would limit the number of limited access Northeast multispecies permits/MRIs an entity can hold to 5%. A 5% cap on permits would amount to 69 MRIs, based on the estimation of total MRIs of 1,373 during FY2014 (Table 47). Of these 1,373 MRIs, 1,240 had non-zero aggregate PSC attached to them, though the cap would apply to any permit, regardless if there is PSC attached to it. The greatest number of MRIs held by an individual or permit bank was 55 as of FY2014 (Section 6.5.4.2). Given the difference between the permit cap and the greatest number of permits owned by an individual or permit bank, Alternative 2 is expected to result in no change in net benefits in the short term. 361 Amendment 18 FEIS Applicable Laws/Executive Orders Table 109 -Summary of the most applicable Amendment 18 goals and MSA National Standards for the analysis of Amendment 18 alternatives Amendment 18 Section  Most Applicable A18 Goal(s)  Most Applicable MSA National Standard(s)  Accumulation Limits  1: Promote a diverse groundfish fishery, including different gear types, vessel sizes, ownership patterns, geographic locations, and levels of participation through sectors and permit banks. 4: Prevent any individual (s), corporation (s), or other entity (ies) from acquiring or controlling excessive shares of the fishery access privileges.  4: Conservation and management measures shall not discriminate between residents of different States. The preferred alternative for acquisition of future holdings (Option C; Section 4.1.2.2) states that only one permit may be acquired over the PSC limit. Under the preferred alternative for the permit cap (Alternative 2; Section 4.1.3), NMFS would not approve the purchase or transfer of a permit that would result in the cap being exceeded. For analysis of the benefits, the preferred alternatives were first considered relative to the Compass Lexicon recommendation of a stock-specific PSC limit of 15.5, which would maintain an unconcentrated level of holdings corresponding to a Herfindahl-Hirschman Index (HHI) of 1500 (Section 6.5.4.4). Under that limit, the resulting environment would be one in which the exertion of market power would, in all likelihood, be prevented. However, there were two major issues with this recommendation: 1) The HHI serves as a warning for the potential for market power to be exerted, but cannot indicate whether or not the exercise is actually occurring. 2) The data provided by NMFS to Compass Lexicon used the same approach to defining holdings as used for Regulatory Flexibility Act (RFA) analyses, looking at holdings at the “business id” level, a broad definition of ownership. The HHI cannot, in fact, be calculated at the individual person level, as the accumulation limit alternatives call for. This is because calculating an HHI requires that the holdings of all the entities equal 100% -the aggregate PSC holdings at the individual level exceed 100. Once again, Compass Lexicon determined that a limit on permit holdings alone would not prevent market power. Section 7.6.2 contains a more detailed discussion of the utility of the Compass Lexicon report. Considering these caveats, it was not possible to definitively state which alternatives could leave the door open for market power to be exerted. What can be analyzed is the PSC attainable given the combination of the recommended permit and PSC cap and to compare these levels with the other Amendment alternatives. A deterministic approach was taken to determine maximum PSC holdings under the preferred alternatives (Table 110). This approach may be considered a “worst case scenario” in terms of the level of accumulation in the fishery, as PSC calculations were made assuming an individual was able to acquire all of the permits with the highest PSC attached to them for a given stock. Under these circumstances, maximum accumulations per stock ranged from a low of 34 (witch flounder) to a high of 73 (GB winter flounder). A probabilistic approach was also taken to determine maximum PSC holdings under the preferred alternatives. A simulation was constructed to select permits at random until either the permit or PSC cap was reached; this simulation was repeated 10,000 times. Fishing year 2013 data was used, with a total of 1,369 MRIs. The simulations were originally run with any MRI, regardless of the amount of PSC attached, equally eligible for selection. Using this approach, the permit cap was met before the PSC cap in all 10,000 trials. To examine when the PSC cap would be more limiting, the simulations were repeated with only permits having aggregate PSC greater than the 50th percentile selected. After the adjustment, there was still only 1 trial out of 10,000 in which the PSC cap was met before the permit cap. Given the importance of the permit cap relative to the PSC cap in terms of preventing PSC accumulation under both simulations, a final 363 simulation was made in which the 75th percentile was the aggregate PSC cutoff point for selection. This cutoff left 342 out of 1,369 MRIs eligible for selection. The simulation that used the 75th percentile selection criteria produced far different results than the 50th percentile criteria or when all permits were eligible for selection. The PSC cap became far more constraining under the revised criteria, and the median accumulation of MRIs was 60, meaning the majority of simulations did not reach the permit cap (and thereby did reach the PSC cap).The results of the 10,000 simulations performed with the 75th percentile selection criteria on an individual stock basis are shown in Figure 26. The median accumulation for all stocks was below 20 PSC; however, some runs did produce individual stock accumulations of 30 or more, particularly for GB winter flounder. Table 110 -Maximum possible PSC acquirable under the preferred alternatives (5% permit cap or 69 MRIs based on 1,373 MRIs in FY 2014 and a PSC cap of 232.5) using a deterministic approach Stock  PSC  MRIs  GB cod  42  49  GOM cod  40  67  GB haddock  49  36  GOM haddock  50  39  GB yellowtail flounder  61  51  SNE/MA yellowtail flounder  65  69  CC/GOM yellowtail flounder  44  57  SNE/MA winter flounder  58  46  GB winter flounder  73  44  GOM winter flounder  64  69  Plaice  41  46  Witch flounder  34  42  Redfish  50  27  Pollock  41  34  White hake  47  38  The probabilistic analysis provides some insight into the level of accumulation possible under the preferred alternatives and if an individual were strategically purchasing permits that had high levels of PSC attached to them (75th percentile or greater). These results should be interpreted with caution however. The simulations performed did not take into account any affinity for acquiring PSC for one stock over another. If an individual would be looking to gain market control in the groundfish fishery, the most economical way of doing so would be to accumulate PSC for a specific stock (a detailed example is in Section 7.6.2). Furthermore, a permit that had a large amount of PSC for only one or two stocks may not be eligible for selection under this simulation. These permits would be the most coveted for an individual looking to gain maximum PSC accumulation for a specific stock while keeping their aggregate accumulation below the PSC cap. 364 Figure 26 -Maximum possible PSC acquirable under the preferred alternatives using a probabilistic approach Note: The PSC cap used in the simulations was equal to 232.5 and the permit cap was 69 MRIs. Stock-specific PSC accumulations over 10,000 simulations with th thth only permits holding aggregate PSC in the 75 percentile or greater eligible for selection. The box in each plot represents the interquartile range (IQR: 25 -75 percentile). The horizontal lines marking the end of the vertical lines extending from the boxes represent the max and min values (1.5*IQR away from the box). Anything above the max or below the min is considered an outlier. 365 Despite the caveats in the probabilistic analysis and the simplicity of the deterministic approach, there are some general takeaways that can be made. First, the preferred alternatives will be more restrictive than the No Action alternatives for the PSC and permit caps, but high levels of accumulation are still theoretically possible (Table 110). Second, the preferred alternatives should be less restrictive than PSC cap Alternatives 2 and 3 with no permit cap. If an individual were looking to accumulate large amounts of PSC, the permits they would most likely look to purchase would be those eligible for selection in the probabilistic simulations. The probabilistic results (Figure 26) show that median accumulation for many stocks is around 15.5. That is, the preferred alternatives will allow an individual to accumulate 15.5 PSC for a given stock and then continue to accumulate PSC until the permit cap is met. If an individual is looking to gain PSC in excess of 15.5 for one or two stocks under the preferred alternatives, they should be able to do so before they reach the permit cap. Third, compared to PSC cap Alternatives 4a and 5 with no permit cap, the preferred alternatives may allow for greater accumulation of PSC for individual stocks, but the level of accumulation will be dependent upon the amount of PSC attached to the permits acquired. The probabilistic analysis found that the preferred alternatives could certainly restrict individuals to PSC levels below those of PSC cap Alternatives 4a and 5 (Figure 26), but the deterministic approach shows accumulation in excess of those permitted under Alternatives 4a and 5 (Table 110). It should be mentioned that, in the absence of any cap on PSC or permits, the ability for an entity to exert market power in the groundfish fishery would likely remain difficult. In terms of a longterm profit-maximizing strategy of an entity, buying up enough permits to yield market power would be a considerable cost, with a payoff that would not be realized for many years, if at all. If an entity did have the means to do so, the fishing activity of the other remaining members of the groundfish fleet would be severely limited. See Section 7.6.2 for further discussion on the effects of market power in the fishery. For the cost side calculation of lost efficiency from PSC and permit caps, there was no clear approach, given the lack of relevant literature on scale economics in the groundfish fishery. The Compass Lexicon report on excessive shares stated that its recommended cap level (15.5 stock-specific PSC) could be achieved without interfering with economies of scale (Mitchell & Peterson 2013; p. 9). The peer review of the report noted that the analytical basis for this conclusion was lacking and gaining a better understanding of the scale economics of the groundfish fishery requires additional data on the cost of operations both at the vessel and group ownership level (Thunberg, et al. 2014). It was impracticable to gather these additional data for this analysis, and therefore the CL report is considered based on the best available science for this action. Consequently, PSC cap Alternative 3 is considered unlikely to interfere with economies of scale in the groundfish fishery, and accordingly, the preferred Alternative 6 would be even less likely to do so. When factoring in the preferred alternative permit cap, the probabilistic analysis shows that the amount of PSC that can be accumulated by an individual is likely to be more restricted. However, the PSC attainable for certain stocks will likely exceed the 15.5 recommendation and, based on the conclusions from the CL report, economies of scale would not be interfered with in any major way. Ultimately, placing an exact dollar value on the long term net benefits of the cap alternatives is not feasible at this time. What can be said with a relatively high level of confidence is that the preferred alternative for a 5% permit cap is likely to be more restrictive than the 15.5 average PSC cap alone. Furthermore, based on probabilistic analysis, the permit cap would allow individuals to gain PSC for a particular stock in excess of the 15.5 CL recommendation. This recommendation, however, is problematic as stated earlier, because: 1) It is based on preventing an HHI of 1500, not in preventing market power, and 2) The method of calculating the HHI was inconsistent with the alternatives provided in Amendment 18. That being said, the best estimate available is that the combination of the PSC and permit cap preferred alternatives are likely to be sufficient in preventing a market power situation from occurring. While further consolidation is certainly possible, if not likely, taking no action would mean that this topic would not be revisited for some time. At that point, the exertion of market power may be more of a concern and there would be less time for action. It is unclear what the probability would be of a market power situation developing under No Action for the cap alternatives. The preferred alternatives have possible benefits, though they cannot be quantified at this time. Similarly, on the cost side, information on the scale economics in the groundfish fishery is lacking. Based on the CL recommendation, economies of scale will be unlikely interfered with. So, while it cannot be definitely stated if the preferred accumulation limit actions yield the highest benefits of the available alternatives, or if other approaches not in the document may be warranted, the average long term net benefits of the preferred alternatives are considered likely positive. 9.11.1.4.2 Handgear A Permit Measures Goal 1 of Amendment 18 is to promote a diverse groundfish fishery, including, among other things, different gear types. Handgear fishing represents a small portion of groundfish fishing effort (Section 6.5.6.3), and Table 111 shows the number of active vessels in the groundfish fishery attached to a Handgear A (HA) permit during FY 2010-2013, as well as the total number of active vessels in the fishery across all permit categories during this time period. Management alternatives with respect to HA permits were developed with the idea of preserving this component of the groundfish fishery. Table 111 -Active HA vessels, in total and common pool only, during FYs 2010-2013. FY2010  FY2011  FY2012  FY2013  Active vessels, across all permit categories, that took a groundfish trip (#).*  446  418  400  327  Total vessels attached to an HA permit that took a groundfish trip* where handgear was used (#).  30  32  24  28  Common pool vessels attached to an HA permit that took a groundfish trip* where handgear was used (#).  30  30  22  27  * As defined in Murphy et al.(2015) ; includes any groundfish trip where revenue was >$0.  Removal of March 1-20 HA Closure Alternative 2 was selected as the preferred alternative for removal of the March 1-20 HA closure. To estimate the additional revenue this action could generate, trips taken by HA permit vessels during Feb-Apr in FY 2012-2014 were considered the most relevant. FY 2010-2011 were excluded, because: 1) common pool closures did not exist during those FYs, and 2) the current groundfish quotas are closer to those during FYs 2012-2014 than FYs 2010-2011. During Feb-Apr in FY 2012-2014, there were 23 groundfish trips taken by HA permit holders resulting in total revenue of $7,593, or $330 per trip. On an annual basis, the average comes out to $2,531 generated. As removing the March 1-20 closure would increase the number of possible fishing days during the Feb-Apr time period by 20 days from roughly 70 to 90, the annual figure was divided by 3.5 (70/20) for a final estimate on revenue generation of $723. In terms of the cost associated with handgear trips, there is, unfortunately, no reliable cost estimate. A proxy considered was the trip cost corresponding to the average for observed single day trips ($335; Das 2014). Given that this estimate exceeds the average revenue generated from Handgear A trips during Feb-Apr in FYs 2012-2014, the net benefits from the preferred alternative is estimated to be negative using this cost estimate. It is assumed that if HA trips taken during March 1-20 would not be profitable, then they would not be taken in the first place. For this reason, the net benefits of this action are estimated to be ≥$0 and <$723. Removal of Standard Fish Tote Requirement Alternative 2 was selected as the preferred alternative for removal of the standard fish tote requirement. Given that the U.S. Coast Guard does not use totes for at-sea enforcement, there is no legal incentive for HA permit holders to carry a tote onboard. It is assumed that there would be no change in net benefits from this alternative, should it be implemented. Sector Exemption from VMS Requirements Alternative 2 was selected as the preferred alternative for the HA sector exemption from VMS requirements. To analyze the potential for HA permit holders to receive net benefits from this alternative, the potential benefit of joining a sector is weighed against the cost of purchasing a VMS unit. From an individual HA permit holders perspective, there are three scenarios that dictate whether or not joining a sector would be worthwhile: 1. If the net benefit of joining a sector is greater than the final cost of purchasing a VMS unit (purchase price minus NMFS reimbursement), the permit holder would be better off joining a sector regardless of whether or not Alternative 2 was implemented. 2. If the net benefit of joining a sector is <$0, the permit holder would be better off not joining a sector, regardless of whether or not Alternative 2 was implemented. 3. If the benefit of joining a sector is >$0, but less than the final cost of purchasing a VMS unit (purchase price minus NMFS reimbursement), the permit holder would be better off joining a sector only if Alternative 2 was implemented. Looking at the cost side of purchasing a VMS unit, there are two approved units listed on the Greater Atlantic VMS Program website (GARFO 2015). One of the unit packages is listed at a price of $2,999, while the other does not have a price available online. The NMFS VMS reimbursement program offers up to $3,100 on a first come basis, meaning it may be possible for HA permit holders to be fully reimbursed for their VMS purchase if they were to enter a sector under the current regulatory environment (Alternative 1). For these individuals, scenario 3 would not apply, and the implementation of Alternative 2 would not affect their decision of whether or not to apply to join a sector. Other individuals likely would not be fully reimbursed; meaning the final cost of purchasing a VMS unit would be up to around $3,000. From the net benefit side of joining a sector, HA permit holders could potentially increase their fishing revenue from joining a sector in two ways. First, trimester quotas do not apply to sector vessels, meaning HA permit holders may be able to avoid closures that would have impacted them in the common pool. Table 67 provides common pool catch by trimester during FY 20102013 as well as when sub-ACLs were exceeded, causing a common pool trimester closure. It should be noted that not included in this table is the Trimester I closure during FY2015, the longest closure that has occurred since trimester sub-ACLs were implemented. The second method by which HA permit holders could potentially increase their revenue from joining a sector is through collaboration with other sector members and the sector manager. By developing strategies to use ACE for a given stock throughout a fishing year, there is a possibility of a decreased “race to fish” in a sector vs. the common pool. This seasonal flexibility would, in theory, allow HA permit holders to receive a higher price for their catch by joining a sector. However, the opposite has held true more often than not, with common pool prices being higher when the stock is highly utilized in the common pool (Table 112). Even if an HA permit holder had increased flexibility and could conceivably receive higher prices on their catch in a sector, the fees that come with being a part of a sector might outweigh any revenue increases. Table 112 -Common pool and sector prices among stocks caught by HA vessels that were highly utilized in the common pool in a given fishing year. Fishing Year and Stock with TAC Utilized >80%  Common Pool Price  Sector Price  2010 GOM Cod  $2.12  $2.28  2011 GOM Cod  $2.41  $2.30  2012 Pollock  $1.04  $1.04  2013 GB Cod  $2.60  $2.03  2013 GOM Haddock  $2.83  $2.11  From a sector’s perspective, allowing an HA permit holder to join is unlikely to yield any significant benefit. The collective PSC held by HA permit holders in the common pool can be converted to only a few thousand pounds of quota given FY2015 specs (Table 10). Furthermore, in FY2013, there were no HA permits that joined a sector that were not part of one in the FY2012. For these reasons, it is assumed that there would be no change in net benefits from this alternative, with the caveat that FY2015 did result in a long common pool closure during Trimester I that is not captured in this analysis. Establish a Handgear A Permit sub-ACL The preferred alternative would not create a sub-ACL for Handgear A permit holders, rather clarify the regulations that it could be created or modified through a future framework action. The net benefits of creating the sub-ACL were calculated nevertheless, and may be used for reference if this alternative is revisited. To estimate the net benefits of creating a HA sub-ACL, all groundfish trips by HA common pool vessels during FYs 2012-2014 were identified by month and statistical area. The average number of trips in each area during each month over the course of the time series was then calculated. Next, all common pool trimester closures during FYs 2012-2014 were retrieved from the Federal Register. Based on these three fishing years, an average number of closure days for each month and statistical area was calculated, as well as the percentage of days closed. Subtracting this percentage from one gave the average % of days open. The number of trips to occur was then divided by the % of days open, producing the number of trips to occur if there were no closures. The difference between the actual number of trips and the theoretical number if no closures occurred gave the number of trips lost, in addition to the associated revenue from those trips. Based on the FY 2012-2014 time series, there were 11.7 trips lost from closures, which would have yielded total revenues of $8,891. At an annual rate, this estimate comes out to $2,964.There is no reliable cost estimate for Handgear A trips. One possibility was to use the average for observed single day trips as a proxy ($335; Das 2014), which would result in total costs of $3,903 from 11.7 trips. Ultimately, applying this cost was not considered appropriate, so the net benefits are estimated to be ≥$0 but <$2,964 annually. In terms of other actions that would work in conjunction with the creation of an HA sub-ACL, the preferred Option (B) for in-season accountability measures would likely have negligible impacts on the net benefits of avoiding common pool closures. Likewise, the preferred Option (A) for reactive accountability measures would also likely have negligible impacts. Preferred Option (A) for discards similarly is likely to have a negligible impact on handgear vessels and the groundfish fleet as a whole with the volume of discards being so low for handgear vessels. Summary In aggregate, the estimated change in net benefits of the preferred alternatives across all HA permits is estimated to ≥$0 and <$723 annually. The lack of benefits stems from the fact that HA permit holders tend to take few trips during the winter, and the few trips taken are generally not as profitable as those taken during the summer. The sector exemption from VMS requirements is also considered unlikely to increase profitability to HA permit holders through joining a sector. The greatest estimated benefit to HA permit holders would likely occur from the establishment of sub-ACLs. Across HA permit holders, the annual net benefits of establishing sub-ACLs is estimated to be ≥$0 and <$2,964. The FY2015 common pool Trimester I closures of Areas 513 and 514 were not included in the analysis, a possible source of underestimation of benefits. These closures applied to all gear types in the common pool and lasted 70 days (6/23/20158/31/2015); by far the longest closures since trimester quotas were introduced in FY2012. Areas 513 and 514 were two of the highest revenue-generating statistical areas to HA permit holders during the summer months of FYs 2012-2014. On the other side, the net benefits of establishing sub-ACLs could be an overestimate due to the fact that the number of active HA permit holders may be lower in the next few fishing years compared to the FY 2012-2014 time series considered if quotas remain low. If this is the case, the net benefit per HA permit holder would not be overestimated, but the aggregate net benefit would be. 9.11.1.4.3 Data Confidentiality Goal 2 of Amendment 18 is to “enhance sector management to effectively engage industry to achieve management goals and improve data quality.” As with any fishery quota lease market, transaction costs exist in the groundfish ACE lease market. In the FY2013 Annual Groundfish Report, the cost of lost leasing opportunities is identified as the largest transaction cost that occurs in the ACE leasing market (Murphy, et al. 2015). It is not clear, however, how large a role the lack of public lease prices play in this transaction cost. Alternative 1 (No Action) was selected as the preferred alternative for this section, meaning the ACE leasing process would be unaltered, and there would be no change in net benefits to the groundfish fishery. Section 4.3.1 acknowledges that ACE price data are not necessary to administer the current regulatory program and making these prices public would require an exemption from the Magnuson-Stevens Act data confidentiality provisions. Alternative 2, which was not preferred, would make price data on trades between sectors available during the fishing year and price data on movement of ACE within sectors available after the end of the fishing year. The net benefits of public pricing are not clear, as possible benefits would rely on the fact that prices made available to the public are an accurate reflection of the leases that occurred. If this is indeed feasible, a reduction in transaction costs would be expected, though the magnitude of this reduction cannot be quantified at this time. It should be noted that the RegulatoryImpact Review “ensures that the regulatory agency systematically and comprehensively considers all available alternatives so that the public welfare can be enhanced in the most efficient and cost-effective way.” While the net benefits of the preferred alternative are not clear, a status quo approach to handling data confidentiality may not necessarily be the best long term approach, if a lack of available information is preventing sector members from leasing ACE more efficiently. This issue, however, may first have to be revisited in the Magnuson-Stevens Act before any change is made at the regional level. 9.11.1.4.4 Inshore/Offshore Gulf of Maine Goal 1 of Amendment 18 is to promote a diverse groundfish fishery, including, among other things, different geographic locations. Many vessels that have traditionally fished in the inshore portion of the Gulf of Maine have exited the fishery in recent years in the face of many challenges, among these, the sizable decreases in Gulf of Maine cod quota and landings (Table 113). Management alternatives to separate the Gulf of Maine into inshore/offshore regions were developed with the idea that spatial management that coincides with the divide between the day-boat and trip-boat fleet could offer better sustainable harvesting opportunities for vessels in the Gulf of Maine. Table 113 -Gulf of Maine cod sub-ACL and landings since implementation of catch shares in FY2010 Fishing Year  Gulf of Maine Cod Commercial Sub-ACL (mt)  Gulf of Maine Cod Landings (mt)  2010  4,567  *3,843  2011  4,825  4,292  2012  3,699  2,084  2013  830  721  2014  830  639  Source: NOAA Fisheries Northeast Multispecies Monitoring Reports *All catch; discard data not available. For reference, discards were 169mt in FY2011.  Alternatives  Inshore/Offshore Boundary  Inshore/Offshore Commercial GOM Cod sub-ACLs  GOM/GB Inshore Restricted Roller Gear Area  Declaration Time Periods for the Commercial Fishery All the preferred alternatives in this section would clarify the regulations that the concepts considered in this section could be created or modified through a future framework action. Should these alternatives be implemented, there would be no change in net benefits to the groundfish fishery. For the alternatives that are not preferred, Alternatives 2A, 2B, and 2C for the creation of an inshore/offshore boundary line would result in no change in net benefits. If however, Alternative 2 for creation of inshore/offshore GOM cod sub-ACLs was selected in conjunction with the boundary line, then net benefits would almost certainly be negative. The amount of fishable PSC for inshore vessels would be reduced and the operational flexibility of the groundfish fleet would be harmed. The magnitude of the negative impacts would also vary depending upon the control rule for the sub-ACL split, whether or not a monitor would be required to fish in both areas, and what the declaration time period to fish in an area would be. The net benefits of Alternative 2 for revision of GOM/GB inshore restricted roller gear area would be uncertain as the size of the restricted area would depend on the creation of an inshore/offshore boundary line. It should be noted that the RegulatoryImpact Review “ensures that the regulatory agency systematically and comprehensively considers all available alternatives so that the public welfare can be enhanced in the most efficient and cost-effective way.” While the preferred alternatives for this section are not expected to result in positive net benefits, a status quo approach to managing the groundfish fishery in the Gulf of Maine may not necessarily be the best long term approach. Under the Section 4.4.1.2 Option B-Establish an inshore/offshore Gulf of Maine boundary at 70°15’W longitude, the rationale states “this line creates a distinction between the day-boat and the trip boat fleets…” If it is determined that the two fleets have to be managed in a different manner so both have the best chance at long term success, this issue could be revisited moving forward. 9.11.1.4.5 Redfish Exemption Area Goal 3 of Amendment 18 is to “promote resilience and stability of fishing business by encouraging, diversification, quota utilization and capital investment.” With limited harvesting opportunities on a number of groundfish stocks, redfish has been identified as a healthy stock that has the ability to support increased landings. The Alternative 2 (to establish the Redfish Exemption Area within the FMP) was developed as a way for groundfish vessels to better target redfish while other groundfish stocks recover. Alternative 1 (No Action) is the preferred alternative for this section. The FY 2015-2016 sector exemption to target redfish using 5.5” mesh would remain in place. The first sector exemption concerning the targeting of redfish with smaller mesh was granted for FY 2012, and modifications to this exemption have been granted for every fishing year since. Redfish landings that that occurred on sector groundfish trips with VTR coordinates north of 42°N and east of 70°W (an area slightly larger than the preferred alternative exemption area) increased dramatically from FY 2011 to FY 2012, before having a somewhat modest decrease in FY2013 (Table 114). For FY2014, redfish landings then increased to a high point in the FY 2011-2014 time series, with of over 8 million pounds landed. Redfish-related revenue from the same area follows a similar trend reached a high point during FY 2012, with FY 2014 slightly behind. Ex-vessel price decreased during the time series from $0.67/lb during FY 2011 to $0.55/lb during FY 2014. This decrease in price is to be expected with a higher landings volume, and with the quantity supplied increasing at a faster rate than the price is decreasing, the demand for redfish may be experiencing a slight increase in recent years. Amendment 18 FEIS Applicable Laws/Executive Orders Table 114 -Redfish and other groundfish catch and revenue on sector groundfish trips within the Redfish Exemption Area Fishing Year  Exemption  Redfish landings (lbs.) Revenue decreased by about $4 million during the same time span from $24.6 million during FY 2011 to $20.7 million during FY 2014. With redfish landings and revenue increasing at the same time, the percent of groundfish revenue coming from redfish on groundfish sector trips occurring north of 42°N and east of 70°W has risen from 11.4% in FY 2011 to 18.1% in FY 2014. To help support increased utilization of redfish, the redfish cooperative research project, or REDNET, is committed to redirecting groundfish fishing to stocks with healthy populations. In their baseline catch and bycatch evaluation report, REDNET found that fishing for redfish using a 4.5” double twine diamond mesh produces a very clean fishery, with redfish accounting for around 95% of total catch in trials. The report also states that targeting of redfish is difficult with the standard 6.5” minimum mesh size allowed in the groundfish fishery (Kanwit, et al. 2013). A REDNET report on codend selectivity under different mesh sizes is also being finalized. The results of this upcoming report should provide a better understanding of the degree to which redfish can be more efficiently targeted under mesh sizes under 6.5”. The expected net benefits of the preferred alternative are $0 assuming the FY 2015-2016 sector exemption remains in place. In the absence of a sector exemption, Alternative 1 would still result in no change in net benefits, but Alternative 2 would result in net benefits >$0. There is no estimate on the benefit associated with the FY 2015-2016 sector exemption. Summary The preferred alternative (No Action) would result in no change in net benefits to the groundfish fishery, assuming the FY15-16 sector exemption remains in place. In the absence, of a sector exemption, Alternative 1 would still result in no change in net benefits, but Alternative 2 would result in net benefits >$0. Moving forward, the Regulatory Impact Review “ensures that the regulatory agency systematically and comprehensively considers all available alternatives so that the public welfare can be enhanced in the most efficient and cost-effective way.” With this in mind, an allowable mesh size of <5.5” should be further researched to determine if redfish targeting can be further improved and what affect a smaller mesh size may have on incidental catch. The REDNET report on codend selectivity has yet to be finalized, but the results should provide a means of economic impact analysis in the future. 9.11.1.5 Determination of Significance The purpose of E.O. 12866 is to enhance planning and coordination with respect to new and existing regulations. This E.O. requires the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) to review regulatory programs that are considered to be “significant” as defined in Section 9.11.1. The preferred alternatives for Amendment 18 to the Northeast Multispecies FMP would not be significant for the purposes of E.O. 12866. To achieve this principle, agencies are required to solicit and consider flexible regulatory proposals and to explain the rationale for their actions to assure such proposals are given serious consideration. The RFA does not contain any decision criteria. Instead, the purpose of the RFA is to inform the agency, as well as the public, of the expected economic impacts of various alternatives contained in the FMP or amendment (including framework management measures and other regulatory actions) and to ensure the agency considers alternatives that minimize the expected impacts while meeting the goals and objectives of the FMP and applicable statutes. With certain exceptions, the RFA requires agencies to conduct an Initial Regulatory Flexibility Analysis (IRFA) for each proposed rule. The IRFA is designed to assess the impacts various regulatory alternatives would have on small entities, including small businesses, and to determine ways to minimize those impacts. An IRFA is conducted to primarily determine whether the Proposed Action would have a “significant economic impact on a substantial number of small entities.” In addition to analyses conducted for the RIR, the IRFA provides: 1. A description of the reasons why action by the agency is being considered; 2. A succinct statement of the objectives of, and legal basis for, the proposed rule; 3. A description and, where feasible, an estimate of the number of small entities to which the proposed rule will apply; 4. A description of the projected reporting, record-keeping, and other compliance requirements of the proposed rule, including an estimate of the classes of small entities which will be subject to the requirements of the report or record; and, 5. Identification, to the extent practicable, of all relevant federal rules, which may duplicate, overlap, or conflict with the proposed rule. 9.11.2.2 Reasons for Considering the Action The purpose and need of Amendment 18 are set forth in Section 3.2 of this document and are incorporated herein by reference. 9.11.2.3 Objectives and Legal Basis for the Action The goals of Amendment 18 are set forth in Section 3.3 of this document and are incorporated herein by reference. 9.11.2.4 Description and Estimate of Small Entities to which the Rule Applies Small entities include "small businesses," "small organizations," and "small governmental jurisdictions." The Small Business Administration (SBA) has established size standards for all major industry sectors in the U.S. including commercial finfish harvesters (NAICS code 114111), commercial shellfish harvesters (NAICS code 114112), other commercial marine harvesters (NAICS code 114119), for-hire businesses (NAICS code 487210), marinas (NAICS code 713930), seafood dealers/wholesalers (NAICS code 424460), and seafood processors (NAICS code 311710). A business primarily involved in finfish harvesting is classified as a small business if it is independently owned and operated, is not dominant in its field of operation (including its affiliates), and has combined annual receipts not in excess of $20.5 million for all its affiliated operations worldwide. For commercial shellfish harvesters, the other qualifiers apply and the receipts threshold is $5.5 million. For other commercial marine harvesters, for-hire businesses, and marinas, the other qualifiers apply and the receipts threshold is $7.5 million. A business primarily involved in seafood processing is classified as a small business if it is independently owned and operated, is not dominant in its field of operation (including its affiliates), and has combined annual employment, counting all individuals employed on a full-time, part-time, or other basis not in excess of 500 employees26 for all its affiliated operations worldwide. For seafood dealers/wholesalers, the other qualifiers apply and the employment threshold is 100 employees. A small organization is any not-for-profit enterprise which is independently owned and operated and is not dominant in its field. Small governmental jurisdictions are governments of cities, boroughs, counties, towns, townships, villages, school districts, or special districts, with population of fewer than 50,000. This Proposed Action regulates commercial fish harvesting entities engaged in the Northeast multispecies limited access fishery. A description of the specific entities that are likely to be impacted is included below for informational purposes, followed by a discussion of those regulated entities likely to be impacted by the proposed regulations. For the purposes of the RFA analysis, the ownership entities, not the individual vessels, are considered as regulated entities. Ownership entities in regulated commercial harvesting businesses Individually-permitted vessels may hold permits for several fisheries, harvesting species of fish that are regulated by several different fishery management plans, even beyond those impacted by the Proposed Action. Furthermore, multiple permitted vessels and/or permits may be owned by entities affiliated by stock ownership, common management, identity of interest, contractual relationships, or economic dependency. For this analysis, ownership entities are defined by those entities with common ownership personnel as listed on permit application documentation. Only permits with identical ownership personnel are categorized as an ownership entity. For example, if five permits have the same seven personnel listed as co-owners on their application paperwork, those seven personnel form one ownership entity, covering those five permits. If one or several of the seven owners also own additional vessels, with sub-sets of the original seven personnel or with new co-owners, those ownership arrangements are deemed to be separate ownership entities for the purpose of this analysis. 26 In determining a concern's number of employees, SBA counts all individuals employed on a full-time, part-time, or other basis. This includes employees obtained from a temporary employee agency, professional employee organization or leasing concern. SBA will consider the totality of the circumstances, including criteria used by the IRS for Federal income tax purposes, in determining whether individuals are employees of a concern. Volunteers (i.e., individuals who receive no compensation, including no in-kind compensation, for work performed) are not considered employees. Where the size standard is number of employees, the method for determining a concern's size includes the following principles: (1) the average number of employees of the concern is used (including the employees of its domestic and foreign affiliates) based upon numbers of employees for each of the pay periods for the preceding completed 12 calendar months; and (2) part-time and temporary employees are counted the same as full-time employees. [PART 121—Small Business Size Regulations §121.106] Regulated commercial harvesting entities Ownership entities are identified on June 1st of each year based on the list of all permit numbers, for the most recent complete calendar year, that have applied for any type of Northeast Federal fishing permit. The current ownership data set is based on calendar year 2014 permits and contains gross sales associated with those permits for calendar years 2012 through 2014. As of June 1, 2015 there were 661 commercial business entities potentially regulated by the Proposed Action (Table 116 and Table 117). These entities are permitted to operate in the Northeast multispecies limited access fishery (as of June 1, 2015 there were 1,147 individual limited access permits.27 649 of these entities are classified as small businesses. 315 entities are primarily engaged in fishing for finfish (that is, obtain the greatest amount of their 2014 gross sales from sales of finfish) and the vast majority is classified as small businesses (average gross revenues from 2012-14 are less than $20.5 million). 237 entities are primarily engaged in fishing for shellfish, and 225 of these are classified as small businesses (average gross revenues from 2012-14 are less than $5.5 million). The 39 for-hire businesses included here are entities affiliated with limited access commercial groundfish permits, but derive greater than 50% of their gross sales from party/charter operations. All are small businesses (average gross revenues from 2012-14 are less than $7.5 million). The remaining 75 entities had no revenue and are classified as small. Table 116 -Entities regulated by the Proposed Action Type  Number  Number small  Primarily finfish  315  315  Primarily shellfish  237  225  Primarily for-hire  34  34  No Revenue  75  75  Total  661  649  These totals may mask some diversity among the entities. In colloquial terms, substantial number refers to “more than a few.” All of the regulated entities impacted by this action are considered small, and this proposed measure will not impact the vast majority of them. Entities which possess a large number of permits and/or a large share of PSC could be slightly negatively impacted if a single individual is in possession of the permits within the entity. Significant economic impacts. The outcome of “significant economic impact” can be ascertained by examining two factors: disproportionality and profitability. Disproportionality refers to whether or not the regulations place a substantial number of small entities at a significant competitive disadvantage to large entities. Profitability refers to whether or not the regulations significantly reduce profits for a substantial number of small entities. Description of impacts on small entities. This IRFA analysis is intended to analyze the impacts of the alternatives described in Section 4.0 on small entities. These measures are expected to minimally impact the small entities regulated by this action. The vast majority (649 out of 661) of potentially regulated entities are classified as small businesses by SBA business size standards. In general, the small entities regulated by this action will be unaffected. The vast majority of limited access groundfish permit holders possess permits and PSC in far smaller quantities than the preferred cap alternatives in Amendment 18. It is possible that the individuals who comprise a part of or the entirety of these small entities could be restricted in the number of permits or the amount of PSC shares they wish to accumulate in the future. Based on the Compass Lexicon report, scalability would not be affected by the reduced accumulation potential (Mitchell & Peterson 2013), although a definitive statement cannot be made at this time. Handgear A permit holders would be largely unaffected by the preferred alternatives. Minimal fishing activity by these vessels occurs during the winter and early spring, and the removal of the March 1-20 closure will not change this behavior. The removal of the standard fish tote requirement would be inconsequential, as this rule is not currently enforced. The sector exemption for VMS requirement would likely also not affect HA permit holders. Joining a sector will remain a challenge for these permit holders, given the lack of PSC they possess. The potential formation of a HA sub-ACL through a future framework could offer opportunity for HA permit holders to avoid trimester closures, such as the considerable event that occurred during Trimester I of FY 2015. Impacts to groundfish-dependent small entities. The impacts on groundfish-dependent small entities will be minimal. No entity will be immediately impacted by the preferred accumulation limits, and few will be potentially impacted in the long term. For those that are potentially impacted, it is not possible to state whether scalability will be lessened. The preferred PSC and permit caps will limit the ability of any individual from monopolizing the fishery. It is not clear how many Handgear A permit holders are groundfish-dependent, but the number is likely very small. There were 28 HA permit holders to take at least one groundfish trip during FY 2013 (Table 111). Any of these 28 would be minimally impacted by the Proposed Action. There may be a few trips taken per during the removed March 1-20 closure block. However, groundfish trips taken by HA permit holders have generally been more profitable during the warmer months in recent years. 10.0 REFERENCES Abernathy A ed. (1989). Journal of Fish Biology. 47(171-173). 11.0 GLOSSARY Annual Catch Limit (ACL): The limit of each groundfish stock that can be harvested by all vessels during each fishing year. Annual Catch Entitlement (ACE): The sum of the PSC for each MRI participating in a sector, multiplied by the commercial groundfish fishery ACL each stock for that year. The product of that multiplication is the ACE for that sector for each stock — the amount of stock in pounds that the sector is allowed to catch for that fishing year. The ACE of each stock equals the sum of PSC times the ACL. Buyout: A federal permit buyout is a capacity reduction program wherein all the funds used to buy permits are the result of appropriation or other federal allocation (i.e., fully funded by the federal government). The permits are then retired from the fishery. Buyback: A federal permit buyback is a specific capacity reduction program outlined in Sections 312(b) and (c) of the MSFCMA wherein industry agrees to a fee system to repay a federally subsidized loan that is used to purchase permits. The permits are then retired from the fishery. Bycatch: (v.) The capture of nontarget species in directed fisheries which occurs because fishing gear and methods are not selective enough to catch only target species. (n.) Fish which are harvested in a fishery but are not sold or kept for personal use, including economic discards and regulatory discards but not fish released alive under a recreational catch and release fishery management program. Capacity: The level of output a fishing fleet is able to produce given specified conditions and constraints. Maximum fishing capacity results when all fishing capital is applied over the maximum amount of available (or permitted) fishing time, assuming that all variable inputs are utilized efficiently. Catch: The sum total of fish killed in a fishery in a given period. Catch is given in either weight or number of fish and may include landings, unreported landings, discards, and incidental deaths. Competitive fringe: A group of numerous small firms, each with 1 – 2% market shares, which cannot profitably influence market prices and will behave competitively. A competitive fringe limits the potential for firms with larger shares to successfully exercise market power. Continental shelf waters: The waters overlying the continental shelf, which extends seaward from the shoreline and deepens gradually to the point where the sea floor begins a slightly steeper descent to the deep ocean floor; the depth of the shelf edge varies, but is approximately 200 m in many regions. Days absent: An estimate by port agents of trip length. These data was collected as part of the NMFS weighout system prior to May 1, 1994. Days-at-sea (DAS): The total days, including steaming time that a boat spends at sea to fish. Amendment 13 categorized DAS for the multispecies fishery into three categories, based on each individual vessel’s fishing history during the period fishing year 1996 through 2001. The three categories are: Category A: can be used to target any groundfish stock; Category B: can only be used to target healthy stocks; Category C: cannot be used until some point in the future. Category B DAS are further divided equally into Category B (regular) and Category B (reserve). Discards: Animals returned to sea after being caught; see bycatch (n.). Essential Fish Habitat (EFH): Those waters and substrate necessary to fish for spawning, breeding, feeding, or growth to maturity. The EFH designation for most managed species in this region is based on a legal text definition and geographical area that are described in the Habitat Omnibus Amendment (NEFMC 1998a). Excessive Shares: “…a share of access rights that would allow a permit owner [holder] or sector to influence to its advantage the prices of the fishery’s output…” (Mitchell & Peterson 2013, p. 2). Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ): A zone in which the inner boundary is a line coterminous with the seaward boundary of each of the coastal States and the outer boundary is line 200 miles away and parallel to the inner boundary Exempt fisheries: Any fishery determined by the Regional Director to have <5% regulated species as a bycatch (by weight) of total catch according to 50 CFR 648.80(a)(7). Fishing effort: The amount of time and fishing power used to harvest fish. Fishing power is a function of gear size, boat size and horsepower. Framework adjustments: Adjustments within a range of measures previously specified in a fishery management plan (FMP). A change usually can be made more quickly and easily by a framework adjustment than through an amendment. For plans developed by the NEFMC, the procedure requires at least two Council meetings including at least one public hearing and an evaluation of environmental impacts not already analyzed as part of the FMP. Individual: For purposes of the accumulation limit alternatives and reporting of permit holdings, the term “individual” means individual human persons, not the MSFCMA definition of a person at § 3(33), which includes any corporation, partnership, association or other entity. Individual Fishing Quota (IFQ): Federal permit under a limited access system to harvest a quantity of fish, expressed by a unit or units representing a percentage of the total allowable catch of a fishery that may be received or held for exclusive use by an individual person or entity Landings: The portion of the catch that is harvested for personal use or sold. Limited-access permits: Permits issued to vessels that met certain qualification criteria by a specified date (the "control date"). Market power: The ability to manipulate prices to one’s advantage based on one’s share of participation in a market (e.g., by withholding supply from the market). Meter (m): A measure of length, equal to 39.37 English inches, the standard of linear measure in the metric system of weights and measures. It was intended to be, and is very nearly, the ten millionth part of the distance from the equator to the North Pole, as ascertained by actual measurement of an arc of a meridian. Metric ton: A unit of weight equal to a thousand kilograms (1kg = 2.2 lb). A metric ton is equivalent to 2,205 lbs. A thousand metric tons is equivalent to 2.2 M lbs. Moratorium Right Identifier (MRI): A unique identifying number that is attached to a Northeast multispecies permit. Each permit has its own MRI, and a given MRI is attached to only one permit. When NMFS calculates Potential Sector Contribution, it uses the MRI history, because this is the best way to determine how much multispecies groundfish has been associated with that permit over time. Multispecies: The group of species managed under the Northeast Multispecies Fishery Management Plan. This group includes whiting, red hake and ocean pout plus the regulated species (cod, haddock, pollock, yellowtail flounder, winter flounder, witch flounder, American plaice, windowpane flounder, white hake and redfish). Northeast Shelf Ecosystem: The Northeast U.S. Shelf Ecosystem has been described as including the area from the Gulf of Maine south to Cape Hatteras, extending from the coast seaward to the edge of the continental shelf, including the slope sea offshore to the Gulf Stream. Observer: Any person required or authorized to be carried on a vessel for conservation and management purposes by regulations or permits under this Act Open access: Describes a fishery or permit for which there is no qualification criteria to participate. Open-access permits may be issued with restrictions on fishing (for example, the type of gear that may be used or the amount of fish that may be caught). Potential Sector Contribution (PSC): The proportion of the total landings of a particular groundfish stock (in live pounds) associated with an individual MRI over a particular period. For most stocks managed by the Northeast Multispecies FMP the PSC is based on a MRI’s landings history during fishing years (FYs) 1996-2006, divided by the landings history of the entire fleet for each stock. Regulated groundfish species: Cod, haddock, pollock, yellowtail flounder, winter flounder, witch flounder, American plaice, windowpane flounder, white hake and redfish. These species are usually targeted with large-mesh net gear. Species composition: A term relating the relative abundance of one species to another using a common measurement; the proportion (percentage) of various species in relation to the total on a given area. Species diversity: The number of different species in an area and their relative abundance. Species richness: See species diversity. A measurement or expression of the number of species present in an area; the more species present, the higher the degree of species richness. Statistical area: A delineated area of ocean used to track where fish were caught. NMFS overlays a grid of statistical areas onto nautical charts to accurately identify specific areas of the ocean. Statistical areas are approximately one degree square although in many cases they do not correspond exactly to specific latitudes and longitudes. Stock: A grouping of fish usually based on genetic relationship, geographic distribution and movement patterns. A region may have more than one stock of a species (for example, Gulf of Maine cod and Georges Bank cod). A species, subspecies, geographical grouping, or other category of fish capable of management as a unit. Stock area: A group of connected statistical areas that defines the geographic distribution of a particular population of an individual species. For example, the Gulf of Maine (GOM) cod stock area comprises statistical areas 464, 465, 467, 510, 511, 512, 513, 514, and 515. All catch of cod in any of these stock areas is attributed to the GOM cod stock. Total Allowable Catch (TAC): The amount (in metric tons) of a stock that is permitted to be caught during a fishing year. This value is calculated by applying a target fishing mortality rate to exploitable biomass. In the Multispecies FMP, TACs can either be “hard” (fishing ceases when the TAC is caught) or a “target” (the TAC is merely used as an indicator to monitor effectiveness of management measures, but does not trigger a closure of the fishery). Valued Ecosystem Component (VEC): A resource or environmental feature that is important (not only economically) to a local human population, or has a national or international profile, or if altered from its existing status, will be important for the evaluation of environmental impacts of industrial developments, and the focusing of administrative efforts. 12.0 INDEX Accountability Measure (AM), 3, 28, 48, 49, 189, 212, 225, 226, 299, 301 Accumulation limit, 1, 9, 32, 35, 44, 66, 67, 156, 176, 206, 208, 222, 236, 254, 270, 335 Amendment 13,
