Amendment 18 To the Northeast Multispecies FMP Appendix I Example methods for determining inshore and offshore Gulf of Maine cod sub-Annual Catch Limits AI-1 Example methods for determining inshore and offshore Gulf of Maine cod Sub-ACLs The Alternatives in Section 4.4.1 and 4.4.2 of Amendment 18 to the Northeast multispecies fishery management plan contemplate creating inshore and offshore sub-Annual Catch Limits (ACLs) for the Gulf of Maine (GOM) cod stock, using one of three possible boundary lines (Options A-C, Section 4.4.1.2). The inshore/offshore proportion could be set based on average fishing effort or GOM cod distribution over the past 10 or 20 year time periods prior to a specifications process. This appendix describes potential methods for calculating this proportion using data from commercial vessel trip reports (VTRs) and Northeast Fisheries Science Center (NEFSC) bottom trawl surveys. 1.0 ESTIMATED PROPORTIONS USING COD LANDING FROM VTR POINT ESTIMATES Proportions of GOM cod landings were determined from VTR point estimates for each boundary option in the GOM cod stock area (Figure 1) on a fishing year basis, for each of the last 20 years (Figure 2). Average proportions for the past 10 and 20 year time periods were also calculated (). This analysis incorporates a large amount of data for commercial trips data that caught GOM cod over a twenty year period. However, the assumption that all cod reported on a VTR is caught at a single point location may not be necessary accurate. VTRs are not designed to collect data on a tow-by-tow basis. The estimated proportion from this analysis also does not incorporate total effort or groundfish targeting behavior. Therefore, landing distributions may not necessarily reflect actual cod stock distributions. For example, increases in total effort may shift east or west (inshore or offshore) depending on the stocks being targeted and/or avoided, and the amount of cod caught with shifting effort will influence the estimated proportions. Figure 1 -Gulf of Maine cod broad stock area AI-2 Amendment 18 FEIS Appendix I Figure 2 -Proportions of GOM cod landings from VTR point estimates for Options A (top), B (middle) and C (bottom) in the GOM cod stock area on a fishing year basis 100% 90% 80% VTR 70% Option 60% 50% east 40% west 30% 20% 10% 0% A 2014 2013 2012 2011 2010 2009 2008 2007 2006 2005 2004 2003 2002 2001 2000 1999 1998 1997 1996 1995 1994 2014 2013 2012 2011 2010 2009 2008 2007 2006 2005 2004 2003 2002 2001 2000 1999 1998 1997 1996 1995 1994 Percent Percent Table 1 -Proportions of GOM cod landings from VTR point estimates for Options A, B and C in the GOM cod stock area on a fishing year basis for the most recent 10 and 20 year average Option A  Option B  Option C  Inshore  Offshore  Inshore  Offshore  Inshore  Offshore  (east)  (west)  (east)  (west)  (east)  (west)  10-year  0.82  0.18  0.76  0.24  0.87  0.13  average  20-year  0.73  0.27  0.64  0.36  0.78  0.22  average  2.0 ESTIMATED PROPORTIONS USING COD WEIGHT PER TOW FROM NEFSC SPRING AND FALL SURVEYS The estimation of proportions of GOM cod biomass relative to a potential boundary (i.e., Option A, B, or C) was calculated using two different methods, since the bottom trawl survey was not specifically designed to estimate biomass distribution relative to these boundaries. Method A: The first method preserves the survey stratified sampling design. Survey tows are randomly assigned based on the stratum area, ranging from about 1 or 2 tows for the smallest stratum to about 8 to 9 tows for the largest stratum. However, the inshore/offshore boundary options do not follow survey stratification boundaries (Figure 3).  Survey strata boundaries in the Gulf of Maine also do not necessary follow the country territory boarders or the statistical area stock boundary lines. Note that some strata have a large amount of area east of the Hague line. In addition, inshore strata north of Massachusetts are not covered by the NEFSC survey and are not included in these calculations. Post stratification of the strata was not possible with the boundary options, due to the breakup of strata into relatively small areas which would not contain tow information. Therefore, the inshore/offshore boundary option’s bisected stratum mean weight per tow was proportionally assigned west or east (i.e., inshore and offshore) according to the area of the stratum west or east. The proportion of area west and east for each option and each stratum was determined using ArcGIS. The total proportion west or east was estimated by summing the mean cod kg per tow for each stratum multiplied by the stratum area west and east (Figure 4 to Figure 6, Table 2). AI-4 Figure 3 -GOM second method ignored the survey stratified sampling design and simply assigned each tow west or east relative to each option’s boundary line (Figure 7), similar to how the above fishery catch-based approach was calculated. The proportion west or east of each boundary option was then calculated by multiplying the mean weight per tow west or east by the total area within the GOM cod broad stock area west or east (Figure 8 to Figure 10, TABLE 3). This method does not include areas outside of the broad stock area in the calculation. It also assumes that the tows reflect cod abundance for the entire area west or east.  For example, cod density in areas not covered by the NEFSC survey (i.e., inshore north of Massachusetts) is assumed to be the same as the other western tows conducted in the survey. Figure 7 -GOM survey stock area (hashed area) east and west relative to the boundary Options A (blue line), B (green line) and C (purple line) Note: Survey strata (gray area) provided as reference. AI-10 Figure 8 -Boundary Option A (70° longitude) spring (top) and fall (bottom) survey proportions ignoring the survey stratification in the calculation AI-11 Figure 9 -Boundary Option B (70°15’ longitude) spring (top) and fall (bottom) survey proportions ignoring the survey stratification in the calculation AI-12 AI-13 Table 3-Boundary Options A, B and C for spring, fall, and combined seasons survey proportions for a 10 and 20 year average ignoring the survey stratification in the calculation Amendment 18 FEIS Appendix I Option A  Option B  Option C  Inshore (east)  Offshore (west)  Inshore (east)  Offshore (west)  Inshore (east)  Offshore (west)  Spring  10-year average  0.88  0.12  0.42  0.58  0.95  0.05  20-year average  0.82  0.18  0.43  0.57  0.89  0.11  Fall  10-year average  0.75  0.25  0.32  0.68  0.84  0.16  20-year average  0.72  0.28  0.37  0.63  0.81  0.19  Combined  10-year average  0.81  0.19  0.37  0.63  0.89  0.11  20-year average  0.77  0.23  0.40  0.60  0.85  0.15  Note: The combined averages use annual estimates from both surveys (i.e., 10 year average is an average of 20 data points and 20 year average is an average of 40 data points).  AI-14 3. Conclusions Depending on which approach and line option is selected to calculate sub-ACLs for GOM cod, the proportion of the GOM cod ACL that would be assigned west (inshore) of the line ranges from 35-95% (Table 1 to Table 3). Examples of possible inshore and offshore sub-ACLs along that range using the proposed FY 2015 commercial sub-ACL (207 mt) for GOM cod in Framework Adjustment 53 are given in Table 4. Table 4 -Possible inshore and offshore sub-ACLs using the Proposed ACL for Gulf of Maine cod in Framework Adjustment 53 for FY 2015 Inshore % inshore sub-ACL (mt) 95% 196.65 90% 186.30 85% 175.95 80% 165.60 75% 155.25 70% 144.90 65% 134.55 60% 124.20 55% 113.85 50% 103.50 45% 93.15 40% 82.80 35% 72.45 Offshore % offshore sub-ACL (mt) 5% 10.35 10% 20.70 15% 31.05 20% 41.40 25% 51.75 30% 62.10 35% 72.45 40% 82.80 45% 93.15 50% 103.50 55% 113.85 60% 124.20 65% 134.55 Notes: FY 2015 GOM cod ABC = 386 mt FY 2015 commercial groundfish ACL = 202 mt (sectors) + 5 mt (common pool) = 207 mt Both the VTR and survey data show an increasing proportion of the stock inshore more recently (10 year versus 20 year average). Similar trends were also seen in the stock assessment. It is important to note the VTR stock proportions are a function of the cod population distribution, fishery effort and groundfish stock targeting behavior. If sub-ACLs can be accurately assigned inshore and offshore consistent with the true cod biomass distributions, then these measures would potentially have low to negligible biological effect on the GOM cod stock, since mortality would not be expected to change much between the components. However, if the GOM cod stock rebounds and/or the distribution changes (i.e., shifting to the east or populating the east and west in different proportions), the impacts on the GOM cod stock could potentially change. It is difficult to determine if those scenarios would result in a positive or negative biological impact on the stock. AI-15 Amendment 18 To the Northeast Multispecies FMP Appendix II Public comments received on the Amendment 18 Draft Environmental Impact Statement CONTENTS 1.0 Summary of Public Comment Period 3 1.1 Introduction 3 1.2 Description of commenters 3 1.3 Comment Summary 5 1.4 Summary 12 2.0 Summary of Oral Hearings 13 2.1 Introduction 13 2.2 Portland, Maine 14 2.3 Portsmouth, New Hampshire 19 2.4 New Bedford, Massachusetts 20 2.5 Mystic, Connecticut 26 2.6 Gloucester, Massachusetts 27 2.7 Webinar 29 3.0 Written comments 30 1.0 SUMMARY OF PUBLIC COMMENT PERIOD 1.1 INTRODUCTION Between July 7 and August 31, 2015, the Council accepted written and oral comments on Amendment 18 to the Northeast Multispecies Fishery Management Plan (A18) and its associated Draft Environmental Impact Statement. Written comments were submitted to National Marine Fisheries Service Regional Administrator John Bullard, and forwarded to the Council by Greater Atlantic Regional Fisheries Office staff. The Council also held six public hearings during this time, moderated by the Groundfish Committee chairman or designee and staffed by Council analysts. At each hearing, public testimony was taken on the measures proposed in the amendment. All of the written (letters) and oral comments (summary and audio recordings) are available for review by the Council and the public. This report provides a summary of the demographics of commenters and the key themes that emerged from the comment period, both specific to A18 and more generally about the Council process and groundfish management. This report does not constitute a response to the comments; rather, it is intended to serve as a guide for Council members and the public as they review the comments. It should not substitute for reading the comments directly. 1.2 DESCRIPTION OF COMMENTERS Oral commenters The six public hearings were attended by 22 stakeholders (two duplicates removed) and 13 individuals provided oral comments (Table 1). There were no commenters at three hearings. Oral comments were received from commercial groundfish fishermen (6, 46%), representatives of non-governmental organizations (NGOs; 5, 38%), and other interested individuals (2, 15%). Of the two people who attended more than one hearing, one did not comment and one commented once. Table 1 – Public hearing attendance Table 2 -Stakeholder type of speakers Location  Attendees*  Speakers  Portland, ME  8  5  Portsmouth, NH  2  0  New Bedford, MA  7  5  Mystic, CT  0  0  Gloucester, MA  6  3  webinar  1  0  Total  24**  13  * Not including Council members or staff ** 22 total attendees if duplicates removed.  Stakeholder Type  Speakers (n,%)  Commercial groundfish fisherman  6 (46%)  Handgear  1 (8%)  Other  5 (38%)  Non-governmental organization  5 (38%)  Environmental  2 (15%)  Commercial  2 (15%)  Other  1 (8%)  Interested public  2 (15%)  Written commenters Eighteen written comments were received during the comment period (late comments excluded). Thus, their letters are not considered further in this summary, which focuses on the stakeholders providing substantive comment. The 16 letters with substantive comments were identified by stakeholder type (Table 3). Half of the letters came from nongovernmental organizations. Of the seven individual letters, four were from commercial groundfish fishermen, two were from recreational fishermen, and one was from a scientist. The one group letter was signed by 40 commercial fishermen; it was not determined how many of those actively groundfish, but many are known to hold groundfish permits. Only one person signed more than one letter, an individual letter and the group letter. Oral and written commenters combined Through the 29 comments (i.e., 13 oral and 16 written), 61 people gave input on Amendment 18, removing duplicates (six people both spoke at a hearing and signed a letter, one person signed two letters). Home state could be determined for all but one commenter; for those representing an NGO, the NGOs physical address was a proxy for home state. The vast majority (90%) of commenters were from either Massachusetts or Maine (Table 4). Other home states were New Hampshire, Rhode Island and Virginia. There were nine NGOs represented, four representing commercial fishing interests, two representing environmental interests, and three representing other fishery interests (Table 5). Table 3 -Stakeholder type of letters Stakeholder Type  Letter (n,%)  Commercial groundfish fisherman  5 (31%)  Non-governmental organization  8 (50%)  Environmental  2 (13%)  Commercial fisheries  3 (19%)  Other fishery interests  3 (19%)  Recreational fisherman  2 (13%)  Scientist  1 (6%)  Table 4 -Home state of commenters State  Stakeholders  #  %  ME  23  38%  NH  3  5%  MA  32  52%  RI  1  2%  VA  1  2%  Unknown  1  2%  Total  61  100%  Table 5 – NGOs commented on A18 Commercial fisheries  Associated Fisheries of Maine  Northeast Coastal Communities Sector  Northeast Hook Fisherman’s Association  Northeast Seafood Coalition  Environmental  Environmental Defense Fund  The Nature Conservancy  Other fishery interests  Health Care Without Harm  Northwest Atlantic Marine Alliance  Penobscot East Resource Center  1.3 COMMENT SUMMARY All public comments received from stakeholders during the public comment period are summarized here. This includes the 16 written comments and summaries of each hearing that contain close (but not exact) transcriptions of the 13 oral comments. All comments were converted into text-searchable formats and imported into a QSR NVivo 10 project for sorting and synthesis. Using this software, topics in the text were highlighted and assigned to a label or “node”. Nodes were also created for each of the 61 people who signed a letter. The comments were then queried to determine how many comments, people, and organizations discussed each topic. Topics were grouped into general concerns about Amendment 18, specific comments on alternatives, comments about the Council process, and comments that are less directly related to this action. Several tables of specific comments are included. The comments in the tables are not listed in any particular order and are numbered simply to facilitate discussion. Where an individual or NGO commented orally and in writing about a topic, they are counted once in the “people commenting” column and twice in the “comments” column. 1.3.1 General concerns about Amendment 18 Although there were many comments stressing the importance of the issues that have been considered through A18, very few comments were complimentary about how the Council has proposed to address these issues. General concerns about Amendment 18 were expressed by 46 individuals and six NGOs via ten written and four oral comments. Table 6 provides the topics of general concern, indicating the number of people representing themselves or an NGO and the number of comments received on each topic. The most common topic, discussed in nine comments by 43 people representing themselves and five people representing NGOs was that Amendment 18 has not addressed concerns relating to fleet diversity and consolidation in a meaningful way. The comments opposed to the Council’s preferences focused on the PSC cap (Alternative 6, 15.5% average of all stocks), indicating that caps should be stock-specific to avoid accumulating too much of a particular stock and to be consistent with the scientific advice that the Council contracted and the A18 goals. Five comments, by two commercial fishermen and two industry NGOs were generally opposed to accumulation limits. Of these, four were supportive of the Council’s preferred alternatives. Rationale included that there are sufficient protections in place to prevent excessive consolidation (e.g., many permit banks and sectors, no Potential Sector Contribution (PSC) splitting) and that caps would prevent achieving optimum yield and prevent the consolidation necessary to achieve the Amendment 16 goals and fleet efficiency. The comments supportive of the Council’s preferences indicated that they would be the least disruptive for the current fishery, consistent with the 5% cap in the scallop fishery, and would not penalize people for the PSC acquired through Amendment 16. Of the comments opposed to the Council’s preferred alternatives, there was not overwhelming support for any other alternative in particular, though there were a few supporters of Alternatives 2, 3, and 4. Other ideas for caps were offered -focus the permit cap on just the permits with PSC greater than zero and have PSC caps of 2-5% per stock. Table 7 – Comments on accumulation limit alternatives Topic  People commenting (#)  Comments (#)  Individual  NGO  Oral  Written  1. Three NGOs commented on the alternatives. Four comments, by two commercial fishermen and two NGOs, supported establishing HA sub-ACLs, in support of the Council’s preferred alternative, citing that it would promote fleet diversity and a future for handgear and improve flexibility for current HA fishermen. One industry NGO suggested setting the annual discard rate at 15%. Regarding the other measures, there was support for the Council’s preferred alternatives of removing the March 1-20 HA closure and the standard tote requirement, and allowing fishing with handgear in a sector to be exempt from using a Vessel Monitoring System. Regarding the concept of establishing sub-ACLs for HA permits, one industry NGO was opposed, citing the concern expressed by NMFS about the inability to accurately monitor such small catch limits. Another concern expressed, even by those who generally support the measures, was that without observer coverage, high-grading may occur, but an acknowledgement that this would apply to less than 1% of the fishery-wide effort. One commercial fisherman suggested creating a sunset provision to avoid abuses. Table 8 – Comments on Handgear A alternatives Topic  People commenting (#)  Comments (#)  Individual  NGO  Oral  Written  1. Three NGOs commented on the alternatives. Three comments, by two commercial fishermen and one environmental NGO, supported the Council’s preferred alternative to establish the Redfish Exemption area within the fishery management plan, citing that the collaborative research that has shone this to be a successful approach to harvesting redfish with low bycatch. The one comment (an industry NGO) opposed to the preferred alternative cited that the exemption is more easily administered through the sector exemption process. All comments were generally supportive of the exemption, though a few noted that the exemption should be closely monitored to ensure that bycatch remains low. One environmental NGO called for 100% monitoring on exemption trips. Table 11 – Comments on Redfish Exemption Area alternatives Topic  People commenting (#)  Comments (#)  Individual  NGO  Oral  Written  1. Two “other fishery interest” NGOs commented on Council process. A disappointment, cited by three comments, representing 42 individuals, is that groundfish management is failing to sustain communities. People pointed to community declines that have occurred during A18 development. Another concern, expressed through three comments (41 individuals and 1 NGO) is that the Council doesn’t take the views of stakeholders seriously. There was frustration that the Council is not considering the input of “ordinary hard-working fishermen.” Particularly related to Amendment 18, there was concern that the document lacks substance to address the public’s scoping comments. Two comments expressed that it is hard for newcomers to the Council and those stakeholders from remote locations to understand the issues and engage in the process. One NGO went as far as to say that the Council is incapable of addressing problems associated with catch shares and has violated public process principles. Table 12 – Comments on Council process Topic  People commenting (#)  Comments (#)  Individual  NGO  Oral  Written  1. Five comments were from NGOs. People feel the Council should be addressing issues that are beyond the scope of Amendment 18, including resolving disparities between stock assessments and what fishermen see though their observations, that the root cause of the fishery’s woes stem from the severe ACL reductions in recent years, the unpredictability of catch advice, and the uncertainty regarding potential industry funding of at-sea monitoring. There was also some opposition to catch share management in general and sector management for groundfish specifically. Some support for trip limits was expressed by commercial fishermen, as well as concern that permit banks may not be helping new entrants and fishing communities as envisioned. Two recreational fishermen addressed recreational bag limits. Ideas for other measures include: • Address the high cost of and inefficiencies in the monitoring program • Improve stability in annual catch limits • Reduce input controls in an output control system • Increase input controls (gear restrictions, trip limits) • Reduce catch of groundfish in other fisheries and/or state waters • Make windowpane accountability measures more economically viable • Protect stock spawning components in the Gulf of Maine Table 13 – Comments beyond Amendment 18 Topic  People commenting (#)  Comments (#)  Individual  NGO  Oral  Written  1. Of the alternatives, the most comments were received about the accumulation limits, with a mix of some support and greater opposition expressed about the Council’s preferred alternatives. No comments were glowingly positive about Amendment 18; all expressed some measure of disappointment. Some felt that Council efforts are better directed on other endeavors, while others felt that A18 has not adequately addressed the concerns that prompted it. There was a general sense that groundfish management is failing to sustain fishing communities. 2.0 SUMMARY OF ORAL HEARINGS 2.1 INTRODUCTION Between August 3-20, 2015, the New England Fishery Management Council (Council) held six public hearings on the Draft Environmental Impact Statement (DEIS) for Amendment 18 to the Northeast Multispecies Fishery Management Plan. These hearings were moderated by the Groundfish Committee chairman or designee and staffed by Council analysts. At each hearing, staff presented the amendment timeline, alternatives under consideration, and draft impacts analysis. After an opportunity to ask questions for clarification, public comments were taken on the measures proposed in the amendment. This document summarizes the public comments made at each hearing. Comments are mostly in the speakerAmendment 18 FEISs own words, but are not exact transcriptions, and may have been edited for clarity and brevity. The attendance estimates for each hearing are based on the attendance sheets signed by audience members, which are available upon request. Based on the attendance sheets, 24 people attended the hearings, although some individuals attended more than one hearing, and additional people may have attended but did not sign in. Testimony was given by 13 individuals. The Council is accepting written comment on Amendment 18 through August 31. Written comments and a summary of all comments will be provided as separate documents. 2.2 PORTLAND, MAINE Holiday Inn by the Bay, 88 Spring St. August 3, 2015 Hearing officer: Frank Blount Other Council members: None Council staff: Rachel Feeney Attendance: Eight audience members (five commenters) Mr. Blount opened the hearing at 6:00 pm, introduced Council staff in attendance, and commented on the Amendment 18 process. Ms. Feeney briefed the audience on the amendment timeline, alternatives under consideration, and draft impacts analysis. After an opportunity to ask questions for clarification, public comments were taken on the measures proposed in the amendment. The hearing closed at 7:15 pm. Questions Kyle Molton (Penobscot East Resource Center) asked if there is impacts analysis available for the accumulation limit alternatives, particularly the impacts to fleet diversity. Staff referred him to the analysis of social and economic impacts in the Draft Environmental Impact Statement, which includes discussion of the potential for fishery consolidation (Section 7.6.2). Hank Soule (Sustainable Harvest Sector) asked for clarification on how accumulation limits would apply to sectors. Staff clarified that the accumulation limit alternatives apply to all individuals and entities. Thus, if a sector holds a limited access groundfish permit(s), it would be subject to whichever alternative is implemented. A sector would not be limited by number of permits/amount of Potential Sector Contribution (PSC) held by individual members of the sector. Mr. Molton also asked that if PSC accumulation limit Alternative 6 is implemented (collective cap across all stocks), what would happen to any excess PSC. How would it be determined which stock would be constrained? Staff indicated that this detail is currently missing from Alternative 6, but was already intending to seek clarification from the Council in September before final action is taken. Jim Odlin (Atlantic Trawlers, Inc., commercial groundfish fisherman, Portland, ME) asked for clarification of PSC accumulation limit Alternative 6. Staff indicated that under that alternative, the average PSC held across all stocks can be no more than 15.5. Thus, with 15 allocated stocks at present, if you add up all one’s PSC, it cannot be more than 232.5 (15.5 x 15). Tim Rider (F/V Finlander, handgear commercial groundfish fisherman, common pool member; Saco, ME) asked if the number of Handgear A (HA) permits renewed in 2014 (n=132) includes permits in Confirmation of Permit History. Staff clarified that it does. Josh Wiersma (Environmental Defense Fund) asked if the data confidentiality Alternative 2 applies to intra-sector as well as inter-sector trades. Staff clarified that it does. Mr. Molton also asked about the timing of implementing Omnibus Habitat Amendment 2 (OHA2) relative to Amendment 18 and how that would impact the no action alternative of Section 4.4.3 regarding the Inshore Roller Gear Restricted Area. Staff clarified that if OHA2 is implemented first, then the no action for Amendment 18 would change to reflect any changes implemented through OHA2. Comments Jim Odlin (Atlantic Trawlers, Inc., commercial groundfish fisherman, Portland, ME): Atlantic Trawlers, Inc. owns five offshore groundfish vessels, employing 30 people. It is my opinion that no accumulation caps are needed. There are numerous permit banks, there are many sectors, most sectors have first right of refusal, no individual or entity owns anything [permits], and species-specific PSC are not able to be split. By any measure, there is no excess consolidation going on now and there has been none documented. Far from it, the fishery is very diverse. Amendment 16 was set up to allow consolidation and recognized that there is too much capacity, given the low ACLs now and likely in the future, and they may be going even lower. Without further consolidation, no one will be able to reach profitability. This is quite obvious if one looks at the economic data available and/or simply looks at the age of fleet. Many vessels are long past their useful life. If you look at Goals 1-3 of Amendment 18, I can’t see how they can possibly be accomplished with accumulation caps put in place. Any accumulation limit will do nothing except allow deep-pocketed companies to consolidate the fleet. There are many ways to do this. You are only kidding yourself and hurting the smaller guys while you say that you want to help then, as has been the past results when regulations have been put in place to help the smaller guy. Seeing that we have the largest scallop company in the world here in New England, despite a cap of 5% on permits, I will offer the following: no individual should be punished for something that is outside their control. On the PSC cap alternatives, if you do decide to go down this crazy road of picking caps, there simply must be a recognition of PSC acquired before the control date. Otherwise, you’ll need some serious justifications for picking something before the control date. You’d have a lot of legal issues, including the issue of takings. For disposition of holdings in excess of that is allowed, I support Option A. We need to be able to keep a balance of stocks in someoneAmendment 18 FEISs holdings. This is the least destructive option. I oppose Options B and C. I oppose PSC cap Alternative 2. It’s too limiting, with no flexibility. It will just make sure every vessel goes broke. It devalues the whole industry and will lead to further underutilization of ACL. Why would you limit a stock that is not being used, such as pollock, redfish, Georges Bank haddock, etc. I also oppose Alternatives 3-5. I reluctantly support Alternative 6, the preferred alternative. It still allows much-needed flexibility and recognizes permit banks and sectors and no splitting of ACL. It will for sure cap the industry at some level that will not allow excessive consolidation while allow some possibility to find profitability. For permit caps, I support the preferred alternative. The 5% permit cap is the same as the scallop fleet. Had you done this a few years ago, it would have allowed management resources to move on to things that could possibly help the industry as a whole, i.e., you would have stopped wasting time on something that has no possible upside. For the data confidentiality measures, I support the preferred alternative. For the inshore/offshore measures, I support the preferred alternative. I have seen nothing that would justify putting in an inshore/offshore line. No one has articulated why they want it or what they are going to do with it. For the redfish exemption measures, I support the preferred alternative. Finally, as with all other regulations, be aware of unintended consequences. As I mentioned before, there is no need for this. These kinds of regulations are easy to get around, and will clearly hurt the smaller fishermen by devaluing their businesses and limiting flexibility. I don’t see a single conservation benefit to any of these proposals. I cannot see any net gain to the Nation by making it impossible to achieve OY, not to mention profitability or the possibility of providing sustainable seafood to the people of this country, who may or may not fish or live near the coast. This simply can’t be the plan. Thank you. Marty Odlin (Atlantic Trawlers, Inc.; commercial groundfish fisherman; Portland, ME): I don’Amendment 18 FEIS’s maximum limit, so it’s not really going to help anyone get into the industry. It’s just going to devalue the permits that exist. Most of the rules aren’t going to add a conservation effort. I don’t see the point. They are just going to cause more problems and confusion, and make it harder for people to operate. Thanks. Tim Rider (F/V Finlander, handgear commercial groundfish fisherman, common pool member; Saco, ME): I’m here to support the measures for the handgear proposal. We definitely need a change in what’s happening. This is a good start. It’s not a lot of fish, but if it works, it’s good for all of us. If the stocks are coming back, it’s pretty evident that the system that we have for us now doesn’t work under trimesters. Being able to fish for other species when one stock is closed would be helpful. Right now, there is very little effort in handgear. There was a heavy effort on flounders early in the trimester, which got the common pool closed, and the handgear vessels paid the price for that pretty dearly in the Gulf of Maine this year. Most people can’t fish at all, because they don’t have the range to do that with handgear. The standard tote – not a big deal obviously. On removing the March 1-20 closure, there’s not a lot of us that are equipped to fish in that time of year in New England. I might be one of the only ones, but it’s pretty bad in March, so I don’t really go a lot. There’s not a big presence in March; you might see a few trips, but not enough to make a huge impact. Same thing with the VMS equipment; I can’t even keep VTRs dry on my boat, so I can’t add much else to it. A lot of us are in open boats. I’d like to see our discards as de minimus, because they are. It’s really important that this go through. It’sa small amount of fish. We know that. There are some challenges with it, but it’s a start. We fish a different style gear than everyone else, and we need to have a way to be managed a little differently. There’s very little effort to handgear fish in the Gulf of Maine, and if you do, you are risking your life dearly just to fish now. Thank you. Josh Wiersma (Environmental Defense Fund): Regarding accumulation limits, we oppose the preferred alternative, because overall, EDF is concerned that nothing in Amendment 18 does anything to meet its goals. I think everyone is aware that right now the fleet is in trouble. Consolidation is occurring, because of the dramatic cuts in Annual Catch Limits. What the Compass Lexecon report showed was a level of accumulation that had little to no risk of market power, and identified these two thresholds of 15.5% and 30%, which they identified as a moderate risk of market power. From our perspective, what you’re trying to do is recognize that although today there might not be an issue with excessive shares or excessive control in the fishery, but fish stocks will recover at some point in the future. Fishermen will have opportunities to invest in this fishery. At that point, we need to have safeguards in place to make sure that new entrants have a chance to participate, and that fishermen who are already participating have an equal shot at targeting and accessing the resource. The problem with the preferred alternative for accumulation limits is that it sets the PSC average/aggregate level at a point where, if you compared a potential accumulation portfolio under the preferred alternative with the current max PSC holdings, you’d end up with a situation where someone could specifically target key choke stocks. For everybody, even larger vessels, this is a problem. For example, if every other stock was maintained at its maximum PSC holdings, someone could accumulate 50% of the GOM cod PSC, 30% of the witch flounder, 30% of the plaice and still maintain aggregate PSC holdings that are within the limit. The other issue that we have is with the 5% total accumulation cap on permits. The total number of multispecies permits is in the neighborhood of 1,450 permits, but only about half of those permits have any PSC history on them. What the preferred alternative says is you want to target 5% of the 1,450 permits. Well, half of those permits are going to be off the table anyway. No one is going to be trying to accumulate permits with no catch history. What you really want to be doing is setting a total permit accumulation limit that is consistent with the 750 or so permits that actually have catch history. As a very easy rule of thumb, a more likely and equitable ratio should be 2.5-3%. On data confidentiality, we think that there are opportunities to improve data use and the overall efficiency of the fishery if very small changes were put in place. We realize that the key argument against releasing sector trade information is the confidentiality violation of Magnuson. The problem with limiting data confidentiality is that it promotes a non-transparency culture in the sector Annual Catch Entitlement (ACE) market. It leads to severe inefficiencies in trading due to asymmetrical information, costly market information, and ultimately, we have a nontransparent, inefficient ACE lease market. It’s exasperated both the data management and the ACE underutilization problem. There is an easy fix, and it could fit within the confidentiality restrictions of Magnuson. If only the information on inter-sector trades were made available to only sector participants, not to the entire public, then every player who has invested in this system and has put their fishing businesses as part of the sector system would have a fair and equitable chance of understanding what their ACE is actually worth. I like the analogy of imagining that you are a home owner trying to sell your home in a market where only the buyer has information on the comparable houses in the neighborhood. The seller is likely to accept an offer that is unrepresentative of the actual property value. This situation has evolved in the Northeast fisheries management system of sectors. It could be remedied, either through only exposing inter-sector trade information to other sector members or by aggregating information and not identifying the individuals who are involved in the transactions. If it needs to be more than two transactions, then you could just wait until two or more transactions took place, and then that information could be aggregated, the prices could be averaged, and that could be posted along with the current information that is already posted about the quantity of trades that takes place within the sector system. That information is critical. There is no better way of understanding the dynamic changes in the ecosystem then having a true shadow value of what’s actually going on in the resource. I want to reference a paper by Ragner Arnisan called “Minimum information management.” His premise is that a lot of catch share systems around the world are too costly to get the data that we need to effectively manage them, specifically to be able to set Total Allowable Catch. In New England, it’Amendment 18 FEIS’s theoretically possible that you could back out a socially optimal Total Allowable Catch, based only on looking at the ACE prices throughout the year as a representation of a fishermen’s actual value and their marginal willingness to pay to go fishing. On the redfish preferred alternative, we strongly support it. We feel that it is a well-researched and well-used method for fishermen to increase their catch on redfish, which is an historically underutilized fishery and species. Thank you. Kyle Molton (Penobscot East Resource Center; Northeast Coastal Communities Sector): I will be submitting written comments that speak specifically to the options outlined here. I want to talk about the public hearing process and the challenges it presents for small boats and diverse fishermen, particularly in eastern Maine. I drove 3.5 hours to be here from Stonington. Some fishermen who we work with live two hours further east. The timeframe basically for the entire thing, from now up until the public comment period after final action has been taken, falls smack-dab within the middle of Maine’s lobster fishing season. I understand the need to move these things forward on a timely basis, and obviously this has been delayed significantly, but virtually all of the fishermen in our sector and that we work with are interested in this, but simply don’t have the time at this time of year to get in their car and drive between three and five hours to Portland. Geographically, this is the furthest north and east that there will be an in-person hearing. That probably only represents only half-way up the coast of where we are really talking about the few stocks that this is really going to matter for. Geographically, it’s not very representative. Again, I understand the challenges. With timelines and trying to operate businesses that a lot of these folks have moved into because of the lack of groundfish, this is further driving them away from fishing in the groundfish fishery, being able to comment publically, be involved in the process, and maintain their investment in this fishery. Thank you. 2.3 PORTSMOUTH, NEW HAMPSHIRE Best Western Plus Wynwood Hotel & Suites – 580 U.S. Highway 1 Bypass August 4, 2015 Hearing officer: Frank Blount Other Council members: Amendment 18 FEISCouncil staff: Rachel Feeney, Jonathon Peros Attendance: Two audience members (no commenters) Mr. Blount opened the hearing at 6:15 pm, introduced Council staff in attendance, and commented on the Amendment 18 process. Having a boundary without a clear problem that has been identified and analyzed and that doesn’t solve a problem. The lines in Amendment 18 have no clear directive on why they would be chosen. We can’t support lines in an action without clear understanding of what it is trying to accomplish, rather than saying, “We’Amendment 18 FEIS” That is not quite responsible. What is being discussed for the GOM cod sub-ACL would be unbelievably disruptive on the inshore fleet – the increased monitoring requirements, the reduction of GOM cod due to the east and west split. It works against the goals of the amendment, which is to promote fleet diversity. It would be detrimental to the inshore fleet, and we can’t support that. Dr. Pierce suggested that it would be helpful to the Council if the Northeast Seafood Coalition addresses in its letter the concern expressed by some Council members about the potential consequences of the PSC accumulation limit Alternative 6 that the Council is preferring. Some have said that it may be possible to have an entity having, say, 50% of all of the GOM cod and little of all the rest. They would have 15.5 collectively. There are reasons why some have said that would be unlikely. It would be helpful if you could elaborate. Maggie Raymond (Associated Fisheries of Maine): Regarding the comments of the first speaker, the Plan Development Team (PDT) did look at the claim of a significant shift of effort from offshore to inshore, and did find that there was some, but not enough to support the claim that the offshore boats had fished out the inshore waters. There is analysis available [see DEIS Section 6.5.6.7]. The Council did not ignore this concern; it was seriously investigated by the PDT. 2.7 WEBINAR August 20, 2015 Hearing officer: Frank Blount Other Council members: Libby Etrie Council staff: Rachel Feeney, Jamie Cournane, Lou Goodreau Attendance: One audience member (no commenters) Mr. Blount opened the webinar at 6:15 pm. The one audience member in attendance did not wish to receive the staff presentation and had no comments. The hearing closed at 6:20 pm. Questions none Comments none 3.0 WRITTEN COMMENTS Amendment 18 To the Northeast Multispecies FMP Appendix III Response to public comments received on the Amendment 18 Draft Environmental Impact Statement III-1 Contents 1.0 Introduction......................................................................................................................2 2.0 General concerns about Amendment 18............................................................................2 3.0 Accumulation limit alternatives ........................................................................................3 4.0 Handgear A Permit alternatives ........................................................................................4 5.0 Data confidentiality alternatives........................................................................................4 6.0 Inshore/offshore Gulf of Maine alternatives......................................................................5 7.0 Redfish Exemption Area alternatives................................................................................5 8.0 Comments on Council process..........................................................................................6 9.0 Comments beyond Amendment 18 ...................................................................................6 1.0 INTRODUCTION Public comments on the Amendment 18 Draft Environmental Impact Statement (A18 DEIS) were accepted during a formal comment period, July 7 through August 31, 2015. The DEIS identified the preliminary preferred alternatives selected by the Council in April 2015. Comments were accepted at six public hearings and by letter, email, or facsimile. Through the 29 comments received, 61 people gave input on Amendment 18. The comments were reviewed by the Council at their September 29-October 1, 2015 meeting. The responses below are based on all comments received during the comment period (Appendix II) and the Council’s final deliberations on preferred alternatives at the September-October meeting. 2.0 GENERAL CONCERNS ABOUT AMENDMENT 18 Comments: Although there were many comments stressing the importance of the issues that have been considered through Amendment 18, very few comments were complimentary about how the Council has proposed to address these issues. The most common general topic was that Amendment 18 has not addressed concerns relating to fleet diversity and consolidation in a meaningful way. A similar comment was that A18 is not meeting its own goals. Of those commenters, most feel that the problems that pose a serious threat to the fishery are not being addressed by the Council, though there was not necessarily agreement on what the problems are. Other rationale included that the preferred alternatives in A18 would have little positive impact on the fleet and lead towards further consolidation and loss of diversity. Some recalled the degree of public concern about consolidation as sectors were implemented and are disappointed that A18 has done little to solve what are perceived as shortcomings of Amendment 16. A few expressed that A18 does little to help the fishery today or in the future or went so far as to say that NMFS should reject this action if the alternatives preferred in the DEIS remain. A contrary view is that the fishery has remained quite diverse and consolidation has not been a concern. A few warned that the Council should beware of unintended consequences; there are many ways to avoid being constrained by a cap, should people be inclined to do so. While many commenters want the Council to take more time to develop A18, a few said that too much time has been spent III-2 and that the Council should dispense with this action, and move on to actions that may be more beneficial to the industry in their view. Council response: The Council acknowledges public concern about fleet diversity and fishery consolidation and that many of these concerns have been raised throughout the development of Amendment 18. The Groundfish Committee specifically discussed the range of issues raised during scoping at several of its meetings between 2012 and 2014. Some of the scoping comment themes were incorporated into the alternatives considered in this action and others were not. The Council’s rationale is provided in the FEIS (Section 3.4.3). The Council developed several accumulation limit alternatives. In weighing the potential for fishery consolidation with the potential to constrain current participants (Section 7.6.2), the Council ultimately selected caps that would not constrain current participants – citing a desire to not “punish” fishermen for the Potential Sector Contribution (PSC) they obtained as a result of Amendment 16. The Council took final action on A18 on September 30, 2015, rather than delay, in part, to be able to shift efforts towards issues in the groundfish fishery that threaten the future viability of the fleet, yet are outside the scope of A18. 3.0 ACCUMULATION LIMIT ALTERNATIVES (SECTION 4.1) Comments: Many comments were generally supportive of accumulation limits, but most of these were not supportive of the Council’s preferred alternatives. Rationale for supporting accumulation limits included that there should be as many people and communities participating in the fishery as possible, but that with the preliminary preferred alternatives, fishery consolidation would be allowed to continue. Examples of consolidation in other catch share fisheries were cited. The comments opposed to the Council’s preferences focused on the PSC cap (Alternative 6, 15.5% average of all stocks), indicating that caps should be stock-specific to avoid accumulating too much of a particular stock and to be consistent with the scientific advice that the Council contracted and the A18 goals. A few comments were generally opposed to accumulation limits, though some support for the Council’s preferred alternatives was expressed. Rationale included that there are sufficient protections in place to prevent excessive consolidation (e.g., many permit banks and sectors, no PSC splitting) and that caps would prevent achieving optimum yield and prevent the consolidation necessary to achieve the Amendment 16 goals and fleet efficiency. The comments supportive of the Council’s preferences indicated that they would be the least disruptive for the current fishery, consistent with the 5% cap in the scallop fishery, and would not penalize people for the PSC acquired through Amendment 16. Of the comments opposed to the Council’s preferred alternatives, there was not overwhelming support for any other alternative in particular, though there were a few supporters of Alternatives 2, 3, and 4. Other ideas for caps were offered -focus the permit cap on just the permits with PSC greater than zero and have lower PSC caps, of 2-5% per stock. Council response: Again, The Council developed several accumulation limit alternatives, and in weighing the potential for fishery consolidation with the potential to constrain current participants (Section 7.6.2), the Council ultimately selected caps that would not constrain current participants – citing a desire to not “punish” fishermen for the Potential Sector Contribution they obtained as a result of Amendment 16. After review of the public comment on the DEIS, when the Council took final action on Amendment 18 on September 30, 2015, the Preferred Alternatives were revised to be more restrictive. Once an entity reaches the 15.5% average PSC cap, the Council is recommending that no other permits may be obtained (Section 4.1.2.2). This III-3 revision was made, in part, to respond to public concerns about the potential for fishery consolidation. The Council did not prefer the stock-specific PSC cap alternatives, in part, due to its concern that doing so may aid the transition of the fishery into a Limited Access Privilege Program, which is not the Council’s intent. The Council also cited that the economic analysis indicates that the Preferred Alternatives, in combination, are likely sufficient to prevent market power (Section 7.7.4.5). 4.0 HANDGEAR A PERMIT ALTERNATIVES (SECTION 4.2) Comments: A few comments supported establishing Handgear A (HA) sub-ACLs, in support of the Council’s preliminary preferred alternative, citing that it would promote fleet diversity and a future for handgear and improve flexibility for current HA fishermen. One comment suggested setting the annual discard rate at 15%. One comment was opposed, citing the concern expressed by NMFS about the inability to accurately monitor such small catch limits. Another concern expressed, even by those who generally support the measure, was that without observer coverage, high-grading may occur, but an acknowledgement that this would apply to less than 1% of the fishery-wide effort. One comment suggested creating a sunset provision to avoid abuses. Regarding the other measures, there was support for the Council’s preferred alternatives of removing the March 1-20 HA closure and the standard tote requirement, and to allow a sector to request an exemption from using a Vessel Monitoring System for sector HA vessels. Council response: After review of the public comment on the DEIS, when the Council took final action on Amendment 18 on September 30, 2015, the Preferred Alternatives were revised. Rather than establishing Handgear A sub-ACLs through Amendment 18, the Council recommends allowing them to be created through a framework adjustment process. The Council agreed with the public comments that the creation of a HA sub-ACL would improve flexibility and options for HA fishermen to participate in the groundfish fishery. However, due to currently low ACLs, particularly for Gulf of Maine cod and Georges Bank cod, the Council determined that the HA sub-ACLs may be difficult to administer at this time. Allowing the sub-ACLs to be created through a framework would facilitate the process should catch limits increase in the future. 5.0 DATA CONFIDENTIALITY ALTERNATIVES (SECTION 4.3) Comments: Some comments supported keeping the price of ACE leases confidential, in support of the Council’s preliminary preferred alternative of status quo. One commenter said that he does not care to know price data. Another indicated that the data are not necessary for sector administration. Other commenters were generally supportive of making ACE trade information more transparent, but just one comment specifically supported Alternative 2, making the ACE price data non-confidential. There were comments that ACE use and fishery efficiency would improve with more public information about ACE trading, benefiting fishermen and communities. One comment indicated that the public has a right to know how their resources are being used. One comment suggested that permit banks, in particular need to be more transparent. One comment thought that only inter-sector trades should be made available to sector members, but for others, data could be aggregated (more than one transaction, daily or weekly average) so that individuals could not be identified. Council response: After review of the public comment on the DEIS, when the Council took final action on Amendment 18 on September 30, 2015, a motion to continue to support the No III-4 Action alternative in Section 4.3 carried. Although several Council members were supportive of greater transparency in the ACE trading market, there was sufficient concern about legality of Alternative 2. Some Council members support encouraging NMFS to make the market as transparent as legally possible (e.g., reporting aggregate data), but no specific Council action has been taken. 6.0 INSHORE/OFFSHORE GULF OF MAINE ALTERNATIVES (SECTION 4.4) Comments: Some comments support the Council’s preliminary preferred alternative, status quo, for all measures in this section of alternatives. Rationale included that the Council has not clearly articulated the problem that establishing an inshore/offshore boundary would solve, splitting the GOM cod ACL would be detrimental to the inshore fleet, and that increased monitoring would undoubtedly be necessary – at industry expense. One comment supported the analysis in the DEIS, highlighting that although there has been an effort shift to inshore waters, there has not been enough to support the claim that it is the primary cause of inshore depletion (Section 7.2.4; Appendix I). Other comments were opposed to the status quo, though there was limited support for other alternatives. One comment supported establishing an inshore/offshore boundary to improve data collection for the future development of measures. Another comment supported extending the GOM/GB Inshore Restricted Roller Gear Area to prevent gear conflicts and pulse fishing inshore. A few comments were generally supportive of protecting inshore stocks and/or fishermen. Some comments felt that the concepts have potential, but the Council should do more work to develop alternatives, rather than approve alternatives at this time. Council response: After review of the public comment on the DEIS, when the Council took final action on Amendment 18 on September 30, 2015, a motion to continue to support the No Action alternatives in Section 4.4 failed. This was due, in part, to general support for developing measures that would distinguish inshore and offshore fishing in the Gulf of Maine. However, the Council did not support any of the action alternatives in Section 4.4 either, citing a general interest in the concepts, but a need to further develop alternatives. The Council preferred to further develop these concepts in a future action. 7.0 REDFISH EXEMPTION AREA ALTERNATIVES (SECTION 4.5) Comments: A few comments supported the Council’s preliminary preferred alternative to establish the Redfish Exemption Area within the fishery management plan, citing that collaborative research has shown this to be a successful approach to harvesting redfish with low bycatch. The one comment opposed to the preferred alternative cited that the exemption is more easily administered through the sector exemption process. All comments were generally supportive of the exemption, though a few noted that the exemption should be closely monitored to ensure that bycatch remains low; one comment called for 100% monitoring on exemption trips. Council response: After review of the public comment on the DEIS, when the Council took final action on Amendment 18 on September 30, 2015, a motion to support the No Action alternative in Section 4.5 carried. The Council supports the general concept of this exemption, but feels that it is more appropriate to continue its review and approval through the current sector exemption process rather than establishing it within the fishery management plan. Doing so III-5 allows greater flexibility for adjusting the exemption and promotes sector-driven solutions to fisheries management. 8.0 COMMENTS ON COUNCIL PROCESS Comments: A disappointment cited by most of the commenters was that groundfish management is failing to sustain communities. Comments pointed to community declines that have occurred during Amendment 18 development, while another concern was that the Council does not take the views of stakeholders seriously. There was frustration that the Council is not considering the input of “ordinary hard-working fishermen.” A few comments expressed that it is hard for newcomers to understand the issues and that stakeholders from remote locations find it hard to participate in the process. One commenter said that the Council is incapable of addressing problems associated with catch shares and has violated public process principles. Council response: The Council shares the concerns expressed about the declining state of the groundfish fishery and its associated communities, and devotes a substantial portion of its resources towards mitigating these circumstances. The Council has been actively striving to rebuild the groundfish stocks from their current low levels through multiple management actions and requests to NOAA, via the Northeast Multispecies fishery management plan and other plans. The Council has held 73 public meetings since 2010 in which Amendment 18 was discussed, providing ample opportunity for the public to engage in its deliberative process. Council members have expressed disappointment in the low attendance at the A18 public hearings and the number of letters received. Throughout the process, and particularly when the Council took final action as described above, Council preferences have been influenced by public input. The Council acknowledges that it may not ultimately support the viewpoints of all stakeholders, but continues to value the role of the public in the management of common property resources. 9.0 COMMENTS BEYOND AMENDMENT 18 Comments: Comments indicated that Council should be addressing issues that are beyond the scope of Amendment 18, including resolving disparities between stock assessments and what fishermen see though their observations, that the root cause of the fishery’s woes stem from the severe ACL reductions in recent years, the unpredictability of catch advice, and the uncertainty regarding potential industry funding of at-sea monitoring. There was also some opposition to catch share management, in general, and sector management for groundfish specifically. Some support for trip limits was expressed, as well as concern that permit banks may not be helping new entrants and fishing communities as envisioned. Two comments addressed recreational bag limits. Council response: The Council generally agrees that there are many other issues that need to be addressed in groundfish management. This is, in part, the reason why the Council took final action in September 2015, rather than delay, so that resources could be devoted to issues that are outside the scope of Amendment 18. The Council continues to support catch share management for this fishery, while acknowledging that improvements are still necessary. III-6
